div.p: THE ROAD TO RUIN: A COMEDY.
AS ACTED AT THE LONDON and DUBLIN THEATRES.
DUBLIN; Printed for J. BRA •• , Crow-Street, 1792.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Enter, driving a boy acroſs the ſtage.

lg.l: AWAY! 'Sblood! Run for the Author! We can do nothing till he appears.
Tell him in leſs than five minutes we ſhall have the houſe about our ears!
Oh ſirs! The prompter has miſlaid the prologue, and we are all a mort,
I ſuppoſe our friends above yonder will ſoon be making pretty ſport;
For pity's ſake, ſuffer us to go on without it—Good, dear ſirs, do!
'Twas moſt abominably dull—Zounds! There ſtands the writer. Well, It's very true.
One of our te tum ti heroes was to have ſpoken it, who meaſure nonſenſe out by the yard;
And our chief hope was you'd make too much noiſe for it to be heard.
The author had mounted on the ſtilts of oratory and elocution:
Not but he had a ſmart touch or two, about Poland, France, and the—the revolution;
Telling us that Frenchman, and Poliſhman, and every man is our brother▪
And that all men, ay, even poor negro men, have a right to be free one as well as another!
Freedom at length, ſaid he, like a torrent is ſpreading and ſwelling,
To ſweep away pride and reach the moſt miſerable dwelling:
To eaſe happineſs, art, ſcience, wit, and genius to give birth▪
Ay, to fertilize a world, and renovate old earth!
Thus he went on, not mentioning a word about the play:
For he ſays prologues are blots, which ought to be wiped away:
A gothic practice, and in ſpite of precedent, not the better for being old,
For, if we tell any part of the plot, it then becomes a tale twice told,
And ſuch twice telling can rarely once excite our wonder:
Ergo, he that ſays nothing is leaſt likely to blunder.
Since therefore prologues are bad things at beſt, pray, my good friends,
Never mind the want of one, but live in hopes the play will make amends.

div.stage: [Exit.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE,
div.stage: SCENE, London. Time not twenty-four hours.
div.p: N. B. The paſſages marked with double commas are omitted in repreſentation.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE I. The Houſe of DORNTON.
Mr. DORNTON alone.
div.p: PAST two o'clock and not yet returned!—Well, well!—It's my own fault!—Mr. Smith!
div.stage: Enter Mr. SMITH.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Is Mr. Sulky come in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you ſure Harry Dornton ſaid he ſhould return to-night?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And you don't know where he is gone?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He did not tell me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Angrily] I aſk you if you know!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I believe to Newmarket, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You always believe the worſt!—I'll ſit up no longer—Tell the ſervants to go to bed—And do you hear, ſhould he apply to you for money, don't let him have a guinea.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Very well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I have done with him; he is henceforth no ſon of mine! Let him ſtarve!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He acts very improperly, ſir, indeed.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Improperly! How? What does he do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir! [Alarmed.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Have you heard any thing of—?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: [Confuſed] No—No, ſir—Nothing—Nothing but what you yourſelf tell me.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Then how do you known he has acted improperly▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He is certainly a very good-hearted young gentleman, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Good-hearted! How dare you make ſuch an aſſertion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How dare you, Mr. Smith, inſult me ſo? Is not his gaming notorious; his racing, driving, riding, and aſſociating with knaves, fools, debauchees, and black legs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Upon my word, ſir—I—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But it's over! His name has this very day been ſtruck out of the firm! Let his drafts be returned. It's all ended! [Paſſionately] And obſerve, not a guinea! If you lend him any yourſelf I'll not pay you. I'll no longer be a fond doting father! Therefore take warning! Take warning, I ſay! be his diſtreſs what it will, not a guinea! Though you ſhould hereafter ſee him begging, ſtarving in the ſtreets, not ſo much as the loan or the gift of a ſingle guinea! [With great paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I ſhall be careful to obſerve your orders, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir! [Terror] Why, would you ſee him ſtarve?—Would you ſee him ſtarve and not lend him a guinea? Would you ſir? Would you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir!—Certainly not▪ except in obedience to your orders!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Amazement and compaſſion] And could any orders juſtify your ſeeing a poor unfortunate youth, rejected by his father, abandoned by his friends, ſtarving to death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: There is no danger of that, ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I tell you the thing ſhall happen! He ſhall ſtarve to death! [Horror at the ſuppoſition] I'll never look on him more as a ſon of mine; and I am very certain, when I have forſaken him, all the world will forſake him too. [Almoſt in tears.] Yes, yes! He is born to be a poor wretched outcaſt!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, he ſtill will make a fine man.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Will!—There is not a finer, handſomer, nobler looking youth in the kingdom; no not in the world!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I mean a worthy good man, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How can you mean any ſuch thing! The company he keeps would corrupt a ſaint.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir▪ if you will only tell me what your pleaſure is, I will endeavour to act like a faithful ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I know you are a faithful ſervant, Mr. Smith.— [Takes his hand] I know you are—But you—You are not a father.

div.stage: Enter Mr. SULKY, and Mr. SMITH goes off.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Sulky, have you heard any thing of him?

sp.speaker: Sulky.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And, hay—?[Exceſſively impatient] Any thing conſoling, any thing good?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: No?—No, ſay you!—Where is he? What is he about?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't—? You love to torture me, ſir! You love to torture me.

sp.speaker: Sul,
sp.p: Humph.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake tell me what you have heard!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I love to torture you.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Put me out of my pain! If you are not a tiger, put me out of my pain! [There; read!

p.stage: [Reluctantly drawing a newſpaper out of his pocket.]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Worſe▪

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mercy defend me!—Where? What?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The firſt paragraph in the poſtſcript: the beginning line in capitals.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Reads] The junior partner of the great banking houſe, not a mile from the Poſt-office, has again been touched at Newmarket, for upward of ten thouſand pounds— [Pauſe] It can't be!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why, can it?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How do you know? What proof have you that this is not a lie?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: His own hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Bills at three days ſight to the full amount have already been preſented.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And accepted?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But!—Why!—Were you mad, Mr. Sulky? Were you mad?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I ſoon ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Is not his name ſtruck off the firm?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: They were dated two days before.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The credit of my houſe begins to totter!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well it may!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What the effect of ſuch a paragraph may be I cannot tell!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can—Ruin.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you ſerious, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sul,
sp.p: I am not inclined to laugh—A run againſt the houſe, ſtoppage, diſgrace, bankruptcy.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Really, Mr Sulky, you—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes, I know I offend. I was bred in your houſe, you uſed me tenderly, I ſerved you faithfully, and you admitted me a partner. Don't think I care for myſelf. No, I can ſit at the deſk again. But You! You! Firſt man of the firſt commercial city on earth, your name in the Gazette? Were it mine only I would laugh at it. What am I? Who cares for me?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: "Where is the vile—?"

p.q: Who can tell? With his lords and his ladies, his court friends and his Newmarket friends, his women of wit and his men of ſoul, his blue ſtockings and his black legs!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling] Mr Smith!—Thomas!—William!
Call all the ſervants together, Mr Smith; clerks, footmen, maids, every ſoul! Tell them their young maſter is a ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Mr Smith
sp.p: Very well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir?— [His anger recurring] Bid them ſhut the door in his face! I'll turn the firſt away that lets him ſet foot in this houſe ever again!

sp.speaker: Mr Smith
sp.p: Very well, ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, ſir? Damn your very well, ſir! I tell you it is not very well, ſir. He ſhall ſtarve, die, rot in the ſtreet! Is that very well, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Has a noble heart. A fond father's heart. The boy was a fond youth—But he ſpoiled him; and now he quarrels with himſelf and all the world, becauſe he hates his own folly. [Diſtant knocking heard at the ſtreetdoor.] So! Here is the youth returned [Knocking again.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Dornton, followed by Servants.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't ſtir! On your lives, don't go to the door! Are the bolts and locks all faſtened?

sp.speaker: Servants
sp.p: All, ſir. [Knocking.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't mind his knocking! Go to bed every foul of you inſtantly, and fall faſt aſleep!—He ſhall ſtarve in the ſtreets! [Knocking again] Fetch me my blunderbuſs! Make haſte! [Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene changes to the Street before the Door.
Harry DORNTON, MILFORD, and Poſtillions.
div.p: Poſtillion We ſmoked along, your honour!

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: [Knocks] I know you did. Had you been leſs free with your whip you would have been half a crown richer. Your next ſtep ſhould be to turn drummers, and handle the cat o' nine tails.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: It is very late you honour!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Be gone! I'll give you no more. [Knocks, Exeunt Poſtillions:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Throwing up the ſaſh and preſenting the blunderbuſs, Mr Sulky behind,] Knock again, you ſcoundrel, and you ſhall have the full contents loaded to the muzzle, raſcal!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: So! I ſuſpected dad was in his tantarums.

sp.speaker: Milford
sp.p: You have given him ſome cauſe:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Very true [To his father] Conſider, my dear ſir, the conſequences of lying out all night;

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Be gone, villian:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bad women, ſir; damps, night air!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Watch-houſes, pick-pockets, cut-throats;

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Come, come, ſir— [Shutting down the window]

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: We ſhall not get in:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pſhaw! How little do you know of my father, the door will open in leſs than fifteen ſeconds;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done, for a hundred:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Done, done, [They take out their watches and the door opens] I knew you were had; double or quits we find the cloth laid and ſupper on the table; [Exeunt into the houſe:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No, It won't do,

div.stage: Scene changes to the former Apartment.
Enter HARRY DORNTON, MILFORD, and Footman,

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: My old maſter is in a bitter paſſion, ſir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know it:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: He is gone down to turn the ſervant out of doors that let you in:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Is he? Then go you and let your fellow-ſervant in again:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I dare not ſir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then I muſt. [Exit

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: He enquired who was with my young maſter,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Well:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: And when he heard it was you, ſir, he was ten times more furious, [Exit Footman.

div.stage: Re-enter HARRY DORNTON.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: All's well that ends well. This has been a curſed loſing voyage, Milford:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am a hundred and fifty▪ in,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I ten thouſand out!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I believe I had better avoid▪ your father for the preſent,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think you had. Dad conſiders you as my tempter, the cauſe of my ruin,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And I being in his debt, he conceives he may treat me without ceremony.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, damn it, Jack, do him juſtice; it is not the money you had of him, but the ill advice he imputes to you that galls him:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I hear he threatens to arreſt me;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, he has threatened to ſtrike my name out of the firm, and diſinherit me, a thouſand times:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Oh, but he has been very ſerious in menacing me,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And me too.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You'll be at the tennis-court to morrow?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: What, not to ſee the grand match?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Oh yes, you will.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I am determined:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, over night, you'll waver in the morning;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, It is high time, Jack, to grow prudent:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, my plan is formed: I'll ſoon be out of debt,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How will you get the money?

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: By calculation.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am reſolved on it. What! can't a man of invention and genius out-wit a black-leg?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "Yes, if he will be as great a ſcoundrel."

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: That's not neceſſary. A keen eye a contriving head, a lucky moment and a little algebra will rout the whole hoſt. How many men of rank and honour, having loſt their fortunes, have double recovered them

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And very honourably;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: who doubts it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Nobody, Nobody;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But pray Harry, what is it you find ſo attractive in my late father's amorous relict?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What the widow Warren?

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: She ſeems to think and even reports you are to marry—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Marry? Her? A coquette of forty, who ridiculouſly apes all the airs of a girl! Fantaſtic, ſelfiſh and a fool! And marry? Diſguſting idea! Thou wert philoſophiſing as we drove on the condition of a poſt-horſe—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I would rather be a poſt-horſe, nay the raſcal that drives a poſt-horſe, than the baſe thing thou haſt imagined!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Then why are you ſo often there?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Becauſe I can't keep away:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: What, it is her daughter, Sophia?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Lovely bewitching innocent!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The poor young thing is fond of you?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I ſhould be half mad if I though ſhe was not, yet am obliged to half hope ſhe is not!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: What a queſtion! Am I not a profligate, and in all probability ruined?—Not even my father can overlook this laſt affair—No,—Heigho;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The loſs of my father's will, and the myſtery made of its contents by thoſe who witneſſed it, are ſtrange circumſtances!

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: In which the widow triumphs. And you being a baſtard, and left by law to ſtarve, ſhe willingly pays obedience to laws ſo wiſe.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: She refuſes even to pay my debts.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: And the worthy alderman, your father, being overtaken by death in the ſouth of France, carefully makes a will, and then as carefully hides it where it is not to be found; or commits it to the cuſtody of ſome mercenary knave, who has made his market of it to the widow—So! here comes the ſuppoſed executor of this ſuppoſed will.

div.stage: Enter Mr. SULKY.
div.p: My dear Mr. Sulky, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sulky
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Indeed? I am very ſorry! What's your diſorder?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You,

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Ruin, bankruptcy, infamy!

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: The old ſtory!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: To a new tune.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You are—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: What, my good cynic?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: A faſhionable gentleman.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I know it,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: And faſhionably ruined.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: No—I have a father,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Who is ruined likewiſe:

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Is the Bank of England ruined?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: I ſay ruined. Nothing leſs than a miracle can ſave the houſe. The purſe of Fortunatus could not ſupply you,

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: No; it held nothing but guineas, notes, bills paper for me!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Such effrontery is inſufferable. For theſe five years, ſir, you have been driving to ruin more furiouſly than—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: An ambaſſadour's coach on a birth night. I ſaw you were ſtammering for a ſimile.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Youth mounts the box, ſeizes the reins, and jehus headlong on in the dark; Paſſion and Prodigality blaze in the front, bewilder the coachman, and dazzle and blind the paſſengers; Wiſdom, Prudence, and Virtue are overſet and maimed or murdered; and at laſt Repentance, like the footman's flambeau lagging behind, lights us to dangers when they are paſt all remedy.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Your name is ſtruck off the firm. I was the adviſer

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: You are very kind, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Your father is at laſt determined.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You'll find ſo! And what brought you here, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: A chaiſe and four. [To Milford.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: It might have carried you to a ſafer place. When do you mean to pay your debts?

sp.speaker: Mil
sp.p: When my father's executor prevails on the widow Warren to do me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: And which way am I to prevail?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And which way am I to pay my debts?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You might have more modeſty than inſolently to come and brave one of your principal creditors, after having ruined his ſon by your evil counſel.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—Don't believe a word on't, my good grumbler; I ruined myſelf, I wanted no counſellor,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: My father died immenſely rich; and, though I am what the law calls illegitimate, I ought not to ſtarve

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You have had five thouſand pounds, and are five more in debt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, thanks to thoſe who truſt boys with thouſands,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You would do the ſame now you think yourſelf a man,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Firmly] Indeed I would not.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Had you been watching the widow at home, inſtead of galloping after a knot of gamblers and pickpockets, you might perhaps have done yourſelf more ſervice:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Which way, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The will of your late father is found.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Found?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I have received a letter, from which I learn it was at laſt diſcovered, carefully locked up in a private drawer, and that it is now a full month ſince a gentleman of Montpelier, coming to England, was entruſted with it. But no ſuch gentleman has yet appeared.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: If it ſhould have got into the hands of the widow—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Which I ſuſpect it has,—You are a couple of pretty gentlemen! But beware: misfortune is at your heels, Mr. Dornton vows vengeance on you both, and juſtly. He is not gone to bed▪ and if you have confidence enough to look him in the face, I would have you ſtay where you are,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I neither wiſh to inſult nor be inſulted. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Do you know, ſir, your father turned the poor fellow into the ſtreet, who compaſſionately opened the door for you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes; and my father knows I as compaſſionately opened the door for the poor fellow in return▪

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Very well, ſir—Your fame is increaſing daily:

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: I am glad to hear it:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph! Then perhaps you have paragraphed yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Paragraphed? What? Where?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: In the St. James's Evening:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Stating the exact amount:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Of my loſs?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yours—You march through every avenue to fame, dirty▪ or clean,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well ſaid!—Be witty when you can; ſarcaſtic you muſt be, in ſpite of your teeth. But I like you the better. You are honeſt, you are my cruet of Cayenne, and a ſprinkling of you is excellent:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well, ſir, when you know the ſtate of your own affairs, and to what you have reduced the houſe, you will perhaps be leſs ready to grin.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Reduced the houſe! ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Dornton, with the Newſpaper in his hand,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So, ſir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Bowing] I am happy to ſee you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You are there, after having broken into my houſe at midnight!—And you are here, [pointing to the paper] after having ruined me and my houſe by your unprincipled prodigality! Are you not a ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, ſir: I am only a fool.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Good night to you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Stay▪ where you are, Mr Sulky, I beg you to ſtay where you are, and be a witneſs to my ſolemn renunciation of him and his vices!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I have witneſſed it a thouſand times:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But this is the laſt, Are you not a ſcoundrel, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am your ſon,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [calling] Mr Smith! Bring in thoſe deeds.

div.stage: Enter Mr SMITH,
div.p: You will not deny you are an incorrigible ſquanderer?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will deny nothing,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A nuiſance, a wart, a blot, a ſtain upon the face of nature!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A ſtain that will waſh out ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A redundancy, a negation; a beſotted ſophiſticated incumbrance; a jumble of fatuity; your head, your heart, your words, your actions. all a jargon; incoherent and unintellegible to yourſelf, abſurd and offenſive to others!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The whirlwind is riſing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am whatever you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Bills never examined, every thing bought on credit, the price of nothing aſked, conſcious you were weak enough to wiſh for baubles you did not want, and pant for pleaſures you could not enjoy, you had not the effrontery to aſſume the circumſpect caution of common ſenſe! And to your other deſtructive follies, you muſt add the deteſtable vice of gaming!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Theſe things, ſir, are much eaſier done than defended,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But here—Give me that parchment! [To Mr Smith] The partners have all been ſummoned▪ Look, ſir! Your name has been formally eraſed!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The partners are very kind.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The ſuſpicions already incurred by the known profligacy of a principal in the firm, the immenſc ſums you have drawn, this paragraph, the run on the houſe it will occaſion, the conſternation of the whole city—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: All very terrible, and ſome of it very true.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Paſſionately] Give me the will, Mr Smith! Give me the will! Fond and fooliſh as I have been, read, and you will find I am at laſt reſtored to my ſenſes!—If I ſhould happily outlive the ſtorm you have raiſed, it ſhall not be to ſupport a prodigal, or to reward a gambler!—You are diſ •• herited!—Read!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Your word is as good as the Bank, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I'll no longer act the doting father, faſcinated by your arts!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I never had any art, ſir, except the one you taught me.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I taught you! What? Scoundrel! What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That of loving you, ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Loving me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Moſt ſincerely!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Forgetting his paſſion] Why, can you ſay, Harry—Raſcal! I mean, that you love me?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I ſhould be a raſcal indeed if I did not ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Harry! [Struggling with his feelings] No! Confound me if I do!—ſir, you are a vile—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know I am.

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: And I'll never ſpeak to you more, [Going

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bid me good night, ſir, Mr Sulky here will bid me good night, and you are my father!—Good night, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Good night:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Come, ſir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Struggling with paſſion] I won't!—If I do—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Reproach me with my follies, ſtrike out my name, diſinherit me, I deſerve it all and more—But ſay Good night, Harry!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I won't!—I won't!—I won't!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Poverty is a trifle; we can whiſtle it off—But enmity—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I will not!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sleep in enmity? And who can ſay how ſoundly?—Come! Good night.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I won't! I won't! [runs off.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Say you ſo?—Why then, my noble hearted dad, I am indeed a ſcoundrel!

div.stage: Re-enter Mr. DORNTON.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Good night! [Exit,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Good night! And Heaven eternally bleſs you, ſir! Heigho!—That's ſomething. [Sings,]

lg.l: Time, would let him wiſely paſs,
Is lively briſk and jolly,
All is not quite as it ſhould be; but— [Sings]
Dip but his wings in the ſparkling glaſs,
And he'll drown dull melancholy,
Heigho! [Exit.

div.head: ACT. II.
div.stage: SCENE I, The Houſe of the Widow WARREN,
JENNY and Mrs LEDGER,

sp.speaker: JENNY,
sp.p: I TELL you, good woman, I can do nothing for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ledger.
sp.p: Only let me ſee Mrs Warren,

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: And get myſelf ſnubbed. Not I indeed.

div.stage: Enter SOPHIA, ſkipping.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: La, Jenny! Yonder's my mamma, with a whole congregation of milliners, mantua-makers, mercers, haberdaſhers, lacemen, feathermen, and—and all the world, conſulting about ſecond mourning!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It will be ſix months to morrow ſince the death of my father-in-law; and ſhe has been buſy giving orders for this fortnight that every thing might be brought home and tried on to-day. I do believe ſhe'll ſleep in her new clothes!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How you run on, miſs!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What would my dear grandma' ſay, if ſhe ſaw her? Why ſhe is even fonder of finery than I am!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Sure, miſs, you are not fond of finery?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but I am—I wonder why ſhe won't let me wear high-heeled ſhoes! I am ſure I am old enough! I ſhall be eighteen next Chriſtmas day at midnight, which is only nine months and two days! And ſince ſhe likes to wear ſlips, and ſaſhes, and ringlets and—nonſenſe, like a girl, why ſhould not I have high heels, and gowns and feſtinis, and hoops, and trains, and ſweeps [Mimicking] and—like a woman?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: It's very true what your mamma tells you, miſs; you have been ſpoiled by your old fond grandmother in Glouceſterſhire.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, Jenny, I won't hear you call my dear grandma' names! Though every body told the loving old ſoul ſhe would ſpoil me.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And now your mamma has ſent for you up to town to finiſh your edication.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe began it the very firſt day: There was the ſtay-maker ſent for, to ſcrew up my ſhapes; the ſhoe-maker, to cripple my feet; the hair dreſſer, to burn my hair; the jeweller, to bore my ears; and the dentiſt, to file my teeth.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ah! You came here ſuch a hoyden! [To Mrs Ledger,] What, an't you gone yet, miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, Jenny, how can you be ſo croſs to people? What is the matter with this good woman?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh! Nothing but poverty.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is that all? Here [Rummaging her pocket] give her this half crown, and make her rich.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Rich indeed!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What, is not it enough? La, I am ſorry I ſpent all my money yeſterday! I laid it out in ſweetmeats, cakes, a Canary bird, and a poll parret. But I hope you are not very, very poor?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: My huſband ſerved the late alderman five-and-twenty years. His maſter promiſed to provide for him; but his pitileſs widow can ſee him thrown with a broken heart upon the pariſh,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh dear!—ſtop!—ſtop a bit! [Running off] Be ſure you don't go!

div.stage: Enter Mr SULKY,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your miſtreſs girl?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My name is Jane Cocket, ſir,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Buſy, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Tell her to come down—Don't ſtare, girl, but go and tell your miſtreſs I want her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide] Humph! Mr Black and gruff! [Exit.

div.stage: Re-enter SOPHIA, with great glee.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I've got it! here! take this, good woman; go home and be happy! Take it, I tell you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: who is this? Mrs Ledger! how does your worthy huſband?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Alack, ſir, ill enough, likely to ſtarve in his latter days,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How, ſtarve?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: The widow refuſes to do any thing for him,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Service, age, and honeſty are poor pleas, with affluence, eaſe, and Mrs Warren,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: You, ſir, I underſtand are the late alderman's executor?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can't tell,

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Perhaps you may be able to ſerve my huſband?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I don't know—however, give my reſpects to him: he ſhan't ſtarve: tell him that.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, but take this in the mean time,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Ay; take it, take it, [Exit Mrs Ledger much affected,] And who are you, miſs Charity?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Me, ſir? Oh I—I am my grandma's granddaughter.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sophia Freclove,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Oh!—The widow's daughter by her firſt huſband?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, ſir,

div.stage: Re-enter JENNY,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Coming, ſir—ſo you have ſtolen your mamma's purſe, miſs?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, don't ſay ſo; I only ran away with it! ſhe was bargaining for ſome ſmuggled lace with one of your acquaintance, and I thought I could diſpoſe of her money to better advantage,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Without her conſent,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, to be ſure! I knew I ſhould never diſpoſe of it in that manner with her conſent,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well! here comes your mamma, [Exit.

div.stage: Enter the Widow WARREN, in a fantaſtic girliſh morning dreſs, ſurrounded by Milliners, Mantua-makers. Furriers, Hatters, &c. with their attendants with band-boxes; all talking as they come on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: So you'll be ſure not to forget my chapeau a la Pruſſe, Mr Mincing?

sp.speaker: Hatter.
sp.p: Certainly not, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you'll make a delicate choice of the feathers?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.p: The ſelection ſhall be elegant, madam

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes—I know, Mr Mincing, you're a charming man!—And you let me have my pierrot a la Coblentz by nine in the morning, Mrs Tiffany?

sp.speaker: Mantua-maker.
sp.p: To a minute, maim.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Madam, when you have a moment's leiſure—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be quiet, you fright; don't interrupt me!—And my caraco a la huſſar, and my bavaroiſes a la ducheſſe—And put four rows of pearl in my turban,

sp.speaker: Milliner.
sp.p: Ver vell, me ladyſhip,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you'll all come together, exactly at nine?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We'll all be here! [Going,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And don't forget the white ermine tippets, and the black fox muffs, and the Kamſchatka furs that you mentioned, Mr Weazel!

sp.speaker: Furrier.
sp.p: I'll bring a fine aſſortment, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And, and, and—No; no—you may all go—I can think of nothing elſe—I ſhall remember more tomorrow,

sp.speaker: Hatter and Furrier
sp.p: Thank you, madam! All-together

sp.speaker: Mantua-makerand Girls,
sp.p: Very much obliged to you maim!

sp.speaker: Milliner.
sp.p: Dee ver good bon jour to me ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What was it you were ſaying, Mr Sulky?—Pray child, what have you done with my purſe?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Given it away, ma',

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Given it away, minikin?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes ma',

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Given my purſe away! To whom, for what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, ma', only—only to keep a poor woman from ſtarving,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I proteſt, child, your grandmother has totally ruined you—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Not quite, madam: ſhe has left the finiſhing to you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What were you ſaying, Mr Sulky—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You won't give me leave to ſay any thing madam

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You know you are a ſhocking troubleſome man, Mr Sulky, I have a thouſand things to remember, and can't bear teaſing, it fatigues my ſpirits! ſo pray relate this very urgent buſineſs of yours in a ſingle word—What would you have—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Juſtice,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord, what do you mean!—Do you think I am in the commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes of ſollies innumerable!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a ſad ſavage, Mr. Sulky! And who is it you want juſtice for?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Your late huſband's ſon, John Milford,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Now pray don't talk to me! You are a very intruſive perſon! You quite derange my ideas! I can think of nothing ſoft or ſatisfactory while you are preſent!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Will you hear me, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I can't, I poſitively can't, it is an odious ſubject!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, ma', how can you be ſo croſs to my brother Milford—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your brother, child—Country education!—how often, minikin, have I told you he is no brother of yours,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, ma', he was your huſband's ſon!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, his—Faugh! Odious word—your brother,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, that he is,—For he is in diſtreſs,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And would you now, you who pretend to be a very prudent—ridiculous kind of a perſon, wiſh to ſee me ſquander the wealth of my poor dear dead good man on Mr Milford, and his profligate companions?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Not I indeed, madam; though the profligate to whom you make love ſhould happen to be one of them

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh the monſter,—I make love!—You have no eyes, Mr Sulky! [Walking and exhibiting herſelf] You are really blind!—But I know whom you mean.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I mean young Dornton, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To be ſure you do,—whom could you mean? Elegant youth!—Rapturous thoughts!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I am ſure, ſir, young Mr. Dornton is no profligate,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: [Significantly] You are ſure?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes that I am!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And it's very ſcandalous, very ſcandalous indeed, to ſay he is my ma's lover!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Becauſe he is a fine genteel young gentleman; and you know ma' is—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, minikin, be leſs flippant with your tongue.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why la, ma', you yourſelf know you are too,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go up to your chamber, child,

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I am ſure ma', I ſay it is very ſcandalous to call the handſome Mr Dornton your lover! [Exit ſkipping

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Do you bluſh?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Bluſh indeed!—Bluſh, ha, ha, ha; you are a very unaccountable creature, Mr Sulky—Bluſh at the babbling of a child!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Who is your rival?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! my rival—The poor minikin!—my rival?—But I have a meſſage for you! Now do compoſe your features to ſoftneſs and complacency! Look pleaſant if you can, ſmile for once in your life!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Don't make love to me! I'll have nothing to ſay to you!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Love—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes, you make love to Dornton! Nay you make love to the booby Goldfinch! Even I am not ſecure in your company!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are a ſhocking being, Mr Sulky,—But if you ſhould happen to ſee Mr Dornton, do aſtoniſh your acquaintance: do a good natured thing, and tell him I am at home all day—Love to you? Ha, ha, ha! Oh you figure, you caricatura of tenderneſs—you inſupportable thing! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: [Sighs] Ah!—All labour in vain! [Enter Jenny] ſtand out of the way girl; [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: There ſhe goes! [Looking after the Widow] That's lucky, this way, ſir,

div.stage: Enter Harry DORNTON, followed by his own Servant with bills in his hand.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My miſtreſs is gone up to her toilette, ſir; but I can ſend you ſomebody you may like better, [Exit
Harry Obliging Abigail!— [Looking over his papers] 'ſdeath, what all theſe tradeſmen's bills?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: All, ſir, Mr Smith ſent me after you with them,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When were they brought?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Some laſt night, but moſt this morning,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ill news travels faſt, and honeſty is deviliſh induſtrious. Go round to them all, return their bills, and bid them come themſelves to-day, has Mr Williams the hoſier ſent in his bill?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, ſir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I thought as much—Tell him to come with the reſt, and on his life not fail,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Very well, ſir, [Exit.

div.stage: Enter SOPHIA joyouſly.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh, Mr Dornton, I am glad to ſee you, do you know, I've got the ſong by heart that you was ſo good as to teach me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And do you know, my charming Sophia, you are the moſt delightful, beautiful bewitching ſcholar that ever took leſſon,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, Mr Dornton. I'm ſure I'm very ſtupid!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That you are all intelligence, all grace, all wit,

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: To be ſure my ma' caught me ſinging it, and ſhe was pettiſh; becauſe you know it's all about love and ends with a happy marriage.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But why pettiſh?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, I can't tell, I ſuppoſe ſhe wants to have all the marriage in the world to herſelf! It's her whole talk! I do believe ſhe'd be married every morning that ſhe riſes, if any body would have her!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Think not of her, my ſweet Sophia, but tell me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I dare not aſk,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Leſt I ſhould offend you,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay now, Mr Dornton, that is not right of you! I am never offended with any body, and I am ſure I ſhould not be offended with you! my grandma' always ſaid I was the beſt tempered girl in the world—What is it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Were you—? [Taking her hand] Did you ever know what it is to love?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, now, how could you aſk one ſuch queſtion? You know very well one muſt not tell!—Beſides, you know too one muſt not be in love—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Becauſe—Becauſe I am but a girl—my grandma' has told me a hundred times, it's a ſin for any body to be in love before they be a woman grown, full one-and twenty; and I am not eighteen!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Love they ſay cannot be reſiſted,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ah, but I have been taught better!—It may be reſiſted—Nobody need be in love unleſs they like: and ſo I won't be in love, for I won't wilfully do amiſs. [With great poſitiveneſs] No! I won't love any perſon though I ſhould love him ever ſo dearly,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Aſide] Angelic innocence! [Aloud] Right, lovely Sophia, guard your heart againſt ſeducers.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do you know it is full five weeks ſince Valentine's day; and, becauſe I'm not one-and-twenty, nobody ſent me a valentine!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And did you expect one?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah—, I can't ſay but I did think—! in Glouceſterſhire, if any young man happen to have a liking for a young woman, ſhe is ſure to hear of it on Valentine day. But perhaps Valentine day does not fall ſo ſoon here as it does in the country;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, it is poſſible you may yet receive a valentine.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay now, but don't you go to think that I am aſking for one; for that would be very wrong of me, and I know better—my grandma' told me I muſt never mention nor think of ſuch things till I am a woman, full one-and-twenty grown; and that if I were to find ſuch a thing at my window, or under my pillow or concealed in a plumcake—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A plum-cake?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes: I aſſure you I have heard of a valentine ſent baked in a plum-cake—And ſo if I had one that I muſt ſhew it to her. But you know ſhe is in Glouceſterſhire; And I am ſure I would not ſhew it to ma' for though ſhe is all out and above forty, ſhe would be as jealous as the vengeance! And indeed I would not receive ſuch a thing for the world, no not from the fineſt man on earth, if I did not think him to be a true and faithful, true, true lover,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But how muſt he prove his faith and truth?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why firſt he muſt love me very dearly!—with all his heart and ſoul!—And then he muſt be willing to wait till I am one-and-twenty,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And would not you love in return?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: N—yes, when I come to be one-and-twenty,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Not ſooner?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh no!—I muſt not!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Surely you might if you pleaſed?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but you muſt not perſuade me to that! If you do I ſhall think you are a bad man, ſuch as my grandma' warned me of!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: and do you think me ſo?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do I?—No!—I would not think you ſo for a thouſand thouſand golden guineas!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Aſide] Faſcinating purity!—what am I about? To▪ deceive or trifle with ſuch unſuſpecting affection would indeed be villiany!

sp.speaker: Goldfinch.
sp.p: [Without at a diſtance] is ſhe above? muſt ſee her—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, I here that great, ridiculous. horſe jockey oaf Goldfinch coming up!— [Sighs]—Good bye Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you, Sophia—ſweet Sophia, Heaven bleſs you, my lovely angel! Heigho!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Heigho! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Without] Is ſhe here?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: [Without] I don't know, ſir,

div.stage: Enter GOLDFINCH in a high-collared coat, ſeveral under waiſtcoats, buckſkin breeches covering his calves, ſhort boots, long ſpurs, high-crowned hat, hair in the extreme, &c.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hah; my tight one,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Surveying him] well Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How you ſtare! An't I the go? That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where's the widow,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Gone up to dreſs, and will not be down theſe two hours,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A hundred to eighty I'd ſup up a ſtring of twenty horſes in leſs time than ſhe takes to dreſs her fetlocks, plait her mane, trim her ears, and buckle on her body-clothes,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You improve daily Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be ſure,—That's your ſort!— [Turning round to ſhew himſelf] An't I a genus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Quite an original!—you may challenge the whole fraternity of the whip to match you!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Match me, Newmarket can't match me! [ſhewing himſelf]—That's your ſort,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh no! Ha, ha, ha! you are harder to match than one of your own pied ponies—A very different being from either your father or grandfather!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Father or grandfather!—ſhakebags both.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Father a ſugar-baker, grandfather a ſlopſeller—I'm a gentleman—That's your ſort,

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! And your father was only a man of worth,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Kept a gig! [With great contempt]—Knew nothing,—Never drove four;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, but he was a uſeful member of ſociety,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A uſef—! What's that?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! A pertinent queſtion,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A gentleman like me a uſeful member of ſociety!—Bet the long odds nobody ever heard of ſuch a thing!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have not acquired your character in the world for nothing, Charles,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: World!—What does the world ſay?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Strange things—It ſays you have got into the hands of jockeys, Jews, and ſwindlers; and that, though old Goldfinch was in his day one of the richeſt men on 'Change, his ſon will ſhortly become poorer than the pooreſt black-leg at Newmarket,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn the world!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: With all my heart, damn the world, for it ſays little better of me,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bet you ſeven to five the Eclipſe colts againſt the Highflyers, the ſecond ſpring meeting,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I have done with highflyer and eclipſe too—ſo you are in purſuit of the widow?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Full cry!—Muſt have her!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! heigho! you muſt?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: All up with me elſe! If I don't marry the widow I muſt ſmaſh!—I have ſecured the knowing one,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Whom do you mean, the maid?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Promiſed her a hundred on the wedding day.

div.stage: Enter JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My miſtreſs can't ſee you at preſent, gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Can't ſee me? [Vexed] Take Harriet an airing in the phaeton,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What is Harriet your favourite?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be ſure, I keep her:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fine creature,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well bred,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Juſt to my taſte—Like myſelf, free and eaſy. That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A fine woman?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Prodigious! ſiſter to the Iriſh giant, ſix feet in her ſtockings—That's your ſort!—ſleek coat, flowing mane, broad cheſt, all bone,—Daſhing figure in a phaeton—ſky blue habit, ſcarlet ſaſh, green hat, yellow ribbands, white feathers, gold band and taſſel!—That's your ſort,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! heigho,—Why you are a high fellow, Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
To be ſure,—Know the odds!—Hold four in hand—Turn a corner in ſtile!—Reins in form—Elbows ſquare—Wriſt pliant—Hayait!—Drive the Coventry ſtage twice a week all ſummer—Pay for an inſide place—Mount the box—Tip the coachy a crown—Beat the
mail—Come in full ſpeed!—Rattle down the gateway!—Take care of your heads!—Never killed but one woman and a child in all my life—That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide to Goldfinch] Take him with you [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Want a hedge?—Take guineas to pounds precipitate againſt Dragon?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Aſide] Wiſh I could have him a few!—Odd or even for fifty? [Drawing his hand clenched from his pocket]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Odd enough!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will you cut a card, hide in the hat, chuck in the glaſs, draw cuts, heads or tails, gallop the maggot, ſwim the hedgehog, any thing?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nothing,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm up to all—That's your ſort!—Get him with me and pigeon him. [Aſide] Come and ſee my greys—Been to Tatterſall's and bought a ſet of ſix—ſmokers!—Beat all England for figure, bone, and beauty,—Hayait, charmers!—That's your ſort!—Bid for two pair of mouſe ponies for Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! The Iriſh Gianteſs drawn by mouſe ponies!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come and ſee 'em,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Sarcaſtically] No, I am weary of the company of ſtable boys,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why ſo? ſhan't play you any tricks—If they ſquirt water at you, or make the colts kick you, tell me and I'll horſewhip 'em—Arch dogs! Deal of wit!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When they do I'll horſewhip them myſelf,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yourſelf?—'Ware that—Wrong there!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think I ſhould be right,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you!—What—Been to ſchool?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To ſchool!—Why yes—I—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mendoza—Oh!—Good-morrow! [Exit▪

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! There goes one of my friends! Heigho!

div.stage: Enter Milford in haſte, followed by Goldfinch returning Eagerly,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What is it Jack? Tell me!

sp.speaker: Milford
sp.p: Come, Harry we ſhall be too late! They are about to begin, we may have what bets we pleaſe:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where? What?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The great match! The famous Frenchman and Will the marker! A thouſand guineas a ſide!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What tennis?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, the Frenchmen gives fifteen and a biſque,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To Will the marker?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will for a hundred,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Done, done!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I bar the bet; the odds are five to four already:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What, for the mounſeer?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'll take it, five hundred to four.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Done, done!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I bar!—I forget—I have cut, I'll never

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You do for a hundred, [bet another guinea,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done, done! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What a cake!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But you'll go?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes you will. Come, come, the match is begun every body is there! The Frenchman is the firſt player

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It's a noble exerciſe! [in the world!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ay! Cato himſelf delighted in it,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, it was much practiſed by the Romans,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The Romans! who are they?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! will you go or will you not, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I can't Jack, my conſcience won't let me,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Zounds, if we don't make haſte it will be all over,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [In a hurry] Do you think it will? [ſtops ſhort] No—I won't—I muſt not,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Taking hold of his arm] Come along, I tell you,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: They have begun:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Have they?—I'm off! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Still ſtruggling, and Harry retreating] what folly! Come along!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I will not,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Leaving him and going] Well, well, if you're ſo poſitive—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Calling] ſtay Jack; ſtay—I'll walk up the ſtreet with you, but I won't go in,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Double or quits the hundred that you won of me laſt night you do!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I don't for a thouſand!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No, no, the hundred.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I tell you I won't. I won't go in with you,

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: Done for the hundred!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done, done! [Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Parlour of the Tennis-court.
Markers paſſing and repaſſing with Rackets and Balls.
Sheriff's Officer, two Followers, and one of the Markers▪
[Shout.]

sp.speaker: Marker.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Pray is Mr Milford, in the court?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I'll bet you gold to ſilver the Frenchman loſes! Hurrah! [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mr. SMITH, from the court.

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: He is not there,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Are you ſure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: The crowd is very great, but I can neither ſee him nor any of his companions,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Then he will not come:

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: I begin to hope ſo!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: [Examing his writ] "Middleſex to wit—One thouſand pounds—Dornton againſt John Milford."

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: You muſt take none but ſubſtanſtial bail.— [ſhout] what a ſcene!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: He will not be here,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Heaven ſend!

div.stage: Enter Goldfinch and a Marker running acroſs▪

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Is the match begun?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The firſt game is juſt over,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Who loſt?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: the Frenchman!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn the mounſeers! That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: That's one of his companions. I begin to tremble—ſtand aſide! here they both come,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: The ſecond, [ſhout.

div.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON, MILFORD, in haſte.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hear them! I hear them! Come along,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Harry!—You would not go!—You were determined! [ſhout.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Zounds! Come along! [Exit in haſte.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: [Stopping him] A word with you, ſir, if you pleaſe

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: With me? Who are you? What do you want!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You are my priſoner,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Priſoner! Damnation! Let me go!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I muſt do my duty, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Here, here; this is your duty,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: [Advancing] It muſt not be ſir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Mr Smith,—What, at the ſuit of Dornton?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. 'Tis your own fault for leading his ſon to theſe places. He heard you were to bring him here.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Furies!—Marker! [To a Marker paſſing] Tell Harry Dornton to come to me inſtantly!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Yes ſir, [Exit.

div.stage: [Shout.]

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Zounds! Let me go and fee the match—

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: You muſt not, ſir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To another Marker] Marker,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Who wins?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: The Frenchman has the beſt on't,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Tell Harry Dornton I am here in trouble, deſire him to come this moment,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Very well ſir, [ſhout.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To the Officer] I'll give you ten guineas for five minutes!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Take him away ſir,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You muſt come along, ſir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To a Marker returning] have you told him?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: He can't come ſir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Very well, Harry! Very well! [To the ſecond Marker] well, ſir,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: He would not leave the court for a thouſand pounds,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Come, come, ſir! [To his two attendants] bring him along!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Hands off, ſcoundrels! [ſhout] Fiends!

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of Mr Silky.
A Room of Buſineſs, Ledger, Letter-files, Ink-ſtand, &c.
SILKY diſcovered and JACOB entering.

sp.speaker: Silky.
sp.p: Well, Jacob, have you been?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes ſir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, and what news? how is he?—Very bad?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Dead ſir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Overjoyed] Dead?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: As Deborah!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Aſide] I'm a lucky man! [Aloud] Are you ſure he is dead, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I ſaw him with my own eyes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That's right, Jacob! I am a lucky man! And what ſay the people at the hotel? Do they know who he is?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh yes, ſir!—He was rich! A gentleman in his own country!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And did you take care they ſhould not know you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To be ſure, ſir! You had given me my leſſon!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Jacob! That's right!—You are a fine boy! mind me, and I'll make a man of you!—And you think they had heard nothing of his having called on me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Not a word!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Aſide] It was a luckey miſtake! [Aloud] Well, Jacob! Don't ſay a word, and I'll give you—I'll give you a crown!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You promiſed me a guinea, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Did I, Jacob? Did I? Well, well! I'll give you a guinea, but be cloſe: did you call at the widow Warren?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, ſir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And will ſhe ſee me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: She deſires you will be there in an hour,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Very well Jacob—Keep cloſe, not a word about the foreign gentleman, or his having been here a week ago, or his being taken ſuddenly ill and dying! [Aſide] It is a lucky ſtroke!—Cloſe, Jacob, my boy!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But give me the guinea, fir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What now, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, ſir, you may forget—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, there, Jacob; there! you'll be a rich man, Jacob, a cunning fellow, I read it in your countenance, Jacob; cloſe, Jacob, and then—!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll give me another?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Jacob! you'll be a great man, mind what I ſay to you, and you'll be a great man—here's ſomebody coming! go, Jacob, cloſe,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And another guinea? [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This is a luckey ſtroke, [Enter Goldfinch] ſo, Mr. Goldfinch what do you want?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Money—a thouſand pound directly,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Fine talking, Mr. Goldfinch, money's a ſcarce commodity, times are tickliſh!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee I muſt have it,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Give me but good ſecurity, and you know I'm your friend,

sp.speaker: Gold▪
sp.p: Yes, good ſecurity and fifty per cent!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why look you there now, for all you know the laſt annuity I had of you, I gave a full hundred more than was offered by your friend Aaron, the Jew:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My friend? Your friend! You collogue together,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Hear you now! For all you know I have always been your friend; always ſupplied you with money, have not I? And when I ſaw you running to ruin, I never told you of it, did I? I was willing to make all things eaſy!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Eaſy enough, you have pretty well 'eaſed me!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: There is your companion Jack Milford; I ſhall be a heavy loſer by him!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ah! It's all up with poor Jack, he's ſixed at laſt

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Old Dornton has ſent the Nab▪man after him!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And arreſted him?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes he's touched!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Calling] Jacob! [Enter Jacob] Run as faſt as you can to my good friend Mr Strawſhoe, the attorney, and tell him to take out detainders for all the debts I have bought up againſt Mr Milford! make haſte!

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I thought you were Jack Milford's friend too!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: So I am, Mr Goldfinch; but I muſt provide for my family,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come, come!—The bit! Tellee I want the coal directly! ſale at Tatterſall's to-morrow morning! Three Herod brood mares with each an eclipſe colt, would not loſe 'em for all Lombard-ſtreet! ſo will you let me have the bit?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Dear, dear! I tell you I can't Mr Goldfinch,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Then ſome other Jew muſt,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Jew! hear you, hear you, this it is to be the friend of an ungrateful ſpendthrift, calls me Jew! I who go to morning prayers every day of my life, and three times to tabernacle on a Sunday!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, you cheat all day, tremble all night, and act the hypocrite the firſt thing in the morning, [Going.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay but ſtay, Mr Goldfinch, ſtay I want to talk to you—I have a ſcheme to make a man of you,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What? Bind me 'prentice to a uſurer,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pſhaw! you are in purſuit of the widow Warren

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Now what will you give me, and I'll ſecure her to you,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have a deed in my power, I won't tell you what, but I have it, by which I can make her marry the man I pleaſe, or remain a widow all her life; and that I am ſure ſhe will never do if ſhe can help it,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You a deed,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes I,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Shew it me,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not for twenty thouſand pounds—depend upon me, I have it, I tell you I'm your friend, and you ſhall have her, that is on proper conditions—If not, Mr Goldfinch, you ſhall not have her,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Indeed, old Judas, well what are your conditions?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I find the late alderman died worth a hundred and fifty thouſand pounds,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Every farthing, Mr Goldfinch! And my conſcience tells me that, riſk and character and all conſidered, I muſt come in for my thirds,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your conſcience tells you that?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes, it does, Mr Goldfinch—Fifty thouſand is a fair price,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: For the ſoul of a miſer,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If you'll join me, ſay ſo,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not a farthing leſs! What, will there not be a hundred thouſand remaining?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why that's true—it will cut a fine daſh.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: To be ſure it will! Come with me! I'll draw up a ſketch of an agreement. After which we muſt fight cunning—The widow is a vain weak woman—you muſt get her written promiſe,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Written—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Under her own hand; with a good round penalty in caſe of forfeiture,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well ſaid, old one!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not leſs than twenty thouſand pounds! A jury would grant half!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why you're a good one!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That would ſecure ſomething, and we would ſnack,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Dammee you're a deep one,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha! Do you think I am, Mr Goldfinch—ſigned on a ſtamp!

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: You know a thing or two:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha; do you think I do, Mr Goldfinch,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You can teach 'em to bite the bubble,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha! you joke, Mr Goldfinch, you joke.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But the devil will have you at laſt!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord forbid, Mr Goldfinch, don't terrify me—I hate the devil, Mr Goldfinch; indeed I do; I hate the name of him! Heaven keep me out of his fiery clutches.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No: he has you ſafe enough, bait his trap but with a guinea, and he is ſure to find you nibbling—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't talk about the devil, Mr Goldfinch, pray don't; but think about the widow ſecure her,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I muſt have the coal though this evening:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't loſe a moment, Mr Goldfinch;

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Muſt not loſe the eclipſe colts—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pſhaw, Mr Goldfinch, think leſs of the colts and more of the widow, get her promiſe black and white, Goldfinch going

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Turns] Tellee I muſt have 'em,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: All will then be ſafe!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Muſt have 'em. [Exeunt

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: SCENE I, The Houſe of the Widow WARREN,
JENNY and SOPHIA meeting,

sp.speaker: JENNY.
sp.p: OH, miſs! I have got ſomething for you,

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Something for me, what is it, what is it?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: [Her hand behind her] What will you give me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh I'll give you [Feeling in her pocket] La, I've got no money, but I'll give you a kiſs and owe you ſixpence,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No. A ſhilling without the kiſs,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well, well, a ſhilling:

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: There then, [Giving her a ſmall parcel,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, what is it? [Reads] To Miſs Sophia Freelove. And ſuch a beautiful ſeal! it's a pity to break it, [Opening the paper] La, nothing but a plumcake,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Conſidering] Ecod—ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! I do think—As ſure as ſixpence it is!—it is—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is what?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Oh la it is!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: What's the matter with the girl?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ecod Jenny, it is the moſt curious plum-cake you ever ſaw

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I ſee nothing curious about it,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but you ſhall ſee, give me a knife—Oh no, that would ſpoil all,—Look you, Jenny, look—Do but look! [Breaks open the cake and finds a valentine] ha, ha, ha, ha! I told you ſo! The ſweet dear— [Kiſſes it] Did you ever ſee ſuch a plum-cake in your whole life, Jenny?—And look here! [Opening the valentine] Oh, how beautiful,—The ſhape of a honey-ſuckle—What ſhould that mean?—And two doves cooing, but here!—here's the writing,

lg.l: The woodbine ſweet and turtle dove
Are types of chaſte and faithful love,
Ah! were ſuch peace and truth but mine,
I'd glady be your valentine.

sp.p: [Repeating] Were ſuch peace and truth but mine, la, now, Mr Dornton, you know they are yours!

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.p: So, ſo! Mr Dornton ſends you valentines, miſs?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh yes. Jenny he is the kindeſt, ſweeteſt, handſomeſt gentleman!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: You muſt give me that valentine, miſs,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Give it you:

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes, that I may ſhew it to your mamma,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Indeed but don't you think it, I would not give this tiny bit of paper, no, not for a diamond as big—as big as the whole world,—And if you were to téll ma', and ſhe were to take it from me, I'd never love you, nor forgive you, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh but indeed, miſs, I'm not obliged to keep ſecrets for nothing,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, Jenny, you know I am very good to you and here—here!—Don't tell ma', and I'll give you this ſilver thimble. [Exit Jenny

div.stage: Enter Widow WARREN and Mr SULKY,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a very ſhocking perſon, Mr Sulky,—The wild man of the woods broke looſe, do return to your keeper, good Orang Outang; and don't go about to terrify the children!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I tell you, madam, Mr Milford is arreſted,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: My brother;

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Locked up at a bailiff's in the next ſtreet,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh dear!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And pray now what is that to me,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am not arreſted,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Would you were!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh the ſavage!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The pitileſs only ſhould feel pain. The ſtonyhearted alone ſhould be encloſed by walls of ſtone,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't be croſs with ma', ſir; I'm ſure ſhe'll releaſe my brother,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are ſure, minikin!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, ma'; for I am ſure no ſoul on earth would ſuffer a fellow creature to lie and pine to death, in a frightful dark dungeon, and fed with bread and water:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Your late huſband recommended the payment of his ſon's debts,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Recommended?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But leaving it to my own prudence,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: More's the pity,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which prudence I ſhall follow,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: It will be the firſt time in your life—You never yet followed prudence, you always ran before it;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay come, dear ma', I am ſure you have a pitiful heart! I am ſure you could not reſt in your bed if my poor brother was in priſon!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold your prattle, child,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ah! I'm ſure you'll make him happy, and pay his debts!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why Jenny! [Calling

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Jenny; [Enter Jenny,

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: La, dear ſir, have patience—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You are an angel!—And you are—! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Nay pray, ſir, do ſtay! [Exit. following.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am glad the monſter is gone! He is a very intolerable perſon! Pray, Jenny, how did it happen that Mr. Dornton went away without ſeeing me?

div.stage: Enter Servant and Mr SILKY.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Leave us, Jenny. [Exit Jenny] So, Mr Silky—What is this very urgent buſineſs of yours?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Looking round] Are we ſafe, madam? Will nobody interrupt us; nobody over-hear us?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no—But what is the meaning of this caution?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [After faſtening the door and carefully drawing the Will from his pocket] Do you know this hand-writing, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah!—It is my poor old dear man's, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You have heard of a will he left in France?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Will indeed? He left no will!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes, he did, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I won't believe it! He loved me too well to rob me of a ſingle guinea! Poor ſimple ſoul! I was his darling!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: His darling madam!—With your permiſſion, I will juſt read a ſingle clauſe in which his darling is mentioned! Look, madam; it is thealderman's hand! [Reads] But as I have ſometimes painfully ſuſpected the exceſſive affection which my ſaid wife, Winifred Warren, profeſſed for me during my decline, and that the ſolemn proteſtations ſhe made never to marry again▪ ſhould ſhe ſurvive me, were both done with ſiniſter views, it is my will that, ſhould ſhe marry, or give a legal promiſe of marriage, written or verbal, that ſhe ſhall be cut off with an annuity of ſix hundred a year; and the reſidue of my effects in that caſe to be equally divided between my natural ſon, John Milford, and my wife's daughter, Sophia Freelove.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Six hundred a year! An old dotard! To imagine that a woman of my elegant ideas could exiſt on ſix hundred a year! Brute! Monſter! I hate him now as heartily as when he was alive: But pray, ſir, how came you by this will?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why it was odd enough! And yet eaſy enough! My name is Silky, madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And you know the executor's name is Sulky—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The gentleman that delivered it only made a miſtake of a letter, and give it to Mr. Silky inſtead of to Mr. Sulky!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And where is that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sil,
sp.p: Ah, poor man! He is dead!

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And gone! Was taken ill the very night he parted from me, went to his hotel, was put to bed in a high fever, and carried off in leſs than a week.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And does Mr Sulky know of this will being delivered?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable! It's all cloſe and ſmooth!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So much the better—Come, give it me, and—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Excuſe me there, madam! I can't do that!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My conſcience won't let me! I muſt provide for my family!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And pray what proviſion is this will to make for your family, Mr Silky?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why, madam. I have a propoſal—You know the power of your own charms!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which I believe is more than you do, Mr Silky—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Hah! Don't ſay ſo, madam! Don't ſay ſo!—Would I were a handſome, rich and wellborn youth! But you know Mr Goldfinch?—Ah, ha, ha, ha! I could tell you a ſecr • t!

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: What, that he is dying for me, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah! So ſmitten!—Talks of nothing elſe!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And is that any ſecret, think you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The alderman I find died worth more than a plum and a half—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have talked the matter over with my friend, Mr Goldfinch, and he thinks it but reaſonable, that for a ſecret of ſo much importance, which would almoſt ſweep the whole away, I ſhould receive one third.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand pounds, Mr Silky?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I can't take leſs.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why you are a greater rogue than even I thought you!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord, madam, it's no roguery! It's only a knowledge of the world! A young huſband and a hundred thouſand pounds, or poor ſix hundred a year without any huſband!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a very ſhocking old miſer▪ Mr Silky! A very repulſive ſort of a perſon! What heart you had is turned to ſtone! You are inſenſible of the power of a pair of fine eyes! But I have made a conqueſt that places me beyond your reach—I mean to marry Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Surpriſed] What! Old Mr Dornton, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Old Mr Dornton, man?—I never ſaw the figure in my life! No! The gay and gallant young Mr Dornton! The pride of the city, and the lawful monarch of my bleeding heart!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha▪ ha, ha! Young Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So you may take your will and light your fires with it! You will not make a penny of it in any other way. Mr. Sulky, the executor is Mr. Dornton's partner, and when I marry Mr Dornton he will never inflict the abſurd penalty.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, madam! When you marry Mr Dornton, that he certainly never will! But if any accident ſhould happen to prevent the match, you will then let me here from you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord▪ good man! Don't mention the horrid idea? Do leave me to my delightful meditations! I would indulge in ſoft ſenſibility and dreams of bliſs; and not be diſturbed by dead men's wills, or the ſordid extortions of an avaricious old rogue!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Very well, madam! The ſecret for the preſent remains between ourſelves! You'll be ſilent for your own ſake! Only remember, ha, ha, ha! If you ſhould want me, I live at number 40. My name is on the door. Ha, ha, ha! Mr. Dornton! Good morning, madam: Mr. Dornton: Ha, ha, ha! You'll ſend if you ſhould want me? [Exit laughing

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Jenny! [Calling,]

div.stage: Enter JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I was ſaying, Jenny, pray how did it happeu that Mr, Dornton went away without ſeeing me?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Indeed ma'am, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel youth!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I'm ſure, ma'am, I wonder how you can like him better than Mr. Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr, Goldfinch is very well, Jenny—But Mr, Dornton! Oh incomparable!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I am ſure, ma'am, if I was a rich lady, and a handſome lady, and a fine lady, like you, I ſhould ſay Mr. Goldfinch for my money!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Should you, Jenny? Well, I don't know— [Languiſhing.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Without] Tellee I muſt ſee her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, here he comes!—He is ſuch a boiſterous perſon! [Goes to the glaſs] How do I look Jenny? I proteſt my face is of all colours!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Significantly after examining] You had better go up to your toilette for a minute.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That ſmooth tongued old extortioner has put me into ſuch a flutter—Don't let him go Jenny.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Never fear, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll not ſtay too long.

div.stage: Enter Goldfinch, his Cloaths, Hat, and Boots dirtied by a Fall.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here I am—All alive.

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.p: Dear! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Safe and ſound! Fine kick up!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Have you been thrown?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pitched five-and-twenty feet into a ditch—Souſe!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Dear me!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pretty commence! No matter—Limbs whole—Heart ſound—That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Where did it happen)

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bye road—Back of Iſlington—Had them tight in hand too—Came to a ſhort turn and a narrow lane—Up flew a damned dancing maſter's umbrella—Bounce—Off they went—Road repairing—Wheelbarrow in the way—Craſh—Out flew I—Whiz—Fire flaſhed—Lay ſtunned—Got up—Looked fooliſh—Shafts broke—Snarler and Blackguard both down—Black-and-all-black paying away, pannels ſmaſhed, traces cut, Snarler lamed.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Terrible!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damned mad!—Curſed a few, cut up Black-and-all-black, horſewhipped Tom, took coach and drove here like a devil in a whirlwind!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very well your neck's not broke!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Little ſtiff—No matter—Damn all dancingmaſters and their umbrellas!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: You had better have been here. Mr Goldfinch. You ſtand ſo long, ſhilly ſhally, that you'll be cut out at laſt, If you had but a licence now in your pocket, I'd undertake to have you married in half an hour!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Think? I'm ſure on't,

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: Dammee, I'll poſt away and get one—muſt not loſe her; the game's up if I do—muſt have her; be true to me, and I'll ſecure you the hundred, I'll be back from the Commons in a ſmack!

div.stage: Enter the Widow WARREN.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ah, widow, here am I! [Runs up to her, kiſſes her boiſterouſly, and dirties her clothes,]

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: I proteſt, Mr Goldfinch—was ever the like,— [Looking at herſelf.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Never mind, bruſh off—I'm the lad—been to Hatchet's—beſpoke the wedding-coach,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But—ſir—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pannels ſtripe painted—hammer-cloth fringed—green and white—curtains feſtooned—patent wheels—ſilver furniture—all flaſh—light as a bandbox—trundle and ſpin after my greys like a tandem down hill—paſs—ſhew 'em the road—whurr—whizz-gig,—That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It will be ſuperb,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Superb? [with contempt]—Tellee it will be the thing!—The go—the ſtare—the gape—the gaze—the rich widow and the tight one,—there they go—away they bowl—That's your ſort,

p.q: You have a taſte for theſe things, Mr Goldfinch,
