Taſte,—believe I have—who more?—Phaetons and curricles, parks and pleaſure-grounds—up hill and down—highways and bye-ways"—I'm the boy that ſhall drive you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pardon me, Mr Goldfinch; if a certain event were by the wiſe diſpoſition of providence to take place, I ſhould think proper to drive,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You drive, if you do damn me;

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
I'm chriſtened and called Charles—Charles Goldfinch—The knowing Lad that's not to be had—winter and ſummer—Fair weather and foul—Low ruts
or no ruts—Never take a falſe quarter—No, no, widow—I drive—hayait!—Ah,—Ah get on,—St—St—Touch whitefoot in the flank—Tickle ſnarler in the ear—Cut up the yelper—Take out a fly's eye—Smack crack—That's your ſort,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Mr Goldfinch, you entertain very improper ſuppoſitions concerning—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence [going]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but ſurely Mr—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence—reſolved—Taking it here▪ [Pointing to his forehead]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If retroſpect and—and affection threw no other obſtacles in the way—yet the—the world—prudence,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The world!—prudence,—damn▪ the world, damn prudence,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh but ſir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The world nor nobody elſe has nothing to do with neither your prudence nor mine,—we'll be married immediately,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Immediately, Mr. Goldfinch.!—I— [undecided]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What you won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Mr Goldfinch—I—do not—abſolutely renunciate—but I—wiſh

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It was over—Know▪ you do—go for the licence

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray—Dear Mr Goldfinch—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence, I tellee.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Only a word,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To the wiſe—I'm he—go for the licence—That's your ſort! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch!—I declare— [Exit following.]

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of DORNTON.
Mr. DORNTON, and Mr SMITH.

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Still the ſame hurry, the ſame crowd, Mr Smith,

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: Much the ſame ſir, the houſe never experienced a day like this! Mr Sulky, thinks we ſhall never get through

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Is Milford taken,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Yes ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Unprincipled prodigal! my ſon owes his ruin to him alone. But he ſhall ſuffer,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: My young maſter's tradeſmen are waiting,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p:
Bid them come in, [Exit Mr Smith] All my
own fault, my own fond folly! Denied him nothing, encouraged him to ſpend; and now the unnatural father can coolly think of turning him on the wide pitileſs world; there to ſtarve, pine in a priſon, rot in dungeons, among agues, rheums and loath ſomeneſs!

div.stage: Re-enter Mr SMITH followed by Tradeſmen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: This way gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Zounds! what an army—A vile thoughtleſs profligate!—"Yes, yes, miſery be his portion; he merits it;"

div.stage: Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: [To Mr Dornton,] You are wanted in the counting-houſe ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, I'll be with you in a moment, gentlemen—abandoned ſpendthrift,

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: I don't like all this, what does it mean?

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Danger,

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: He has been a good cuſtomer—None of your punctual paymaſters, that look over their accounts,

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Oh, a different thing! Nothing to be got by them—Always take care to affront them,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Perhaps it is a trick of the old gentleman, to inſpect into our charges;

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: I don't like that—rather hear of any tax than of taxing my bill.

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Humph! Tradeſmen begin to underſtand theſe things, and allow a reaſonable profit!

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Can't have leſs than fifty per cent. for retail credit trade▪

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: To be ſure not; if a man would live in ſtyle, and ſave a fortune as he ought:

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Huſh, mind—All deviliſh hard run,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly!

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Not a guinea in the houſe!—To-morrow's Saturday—Hem!

div.stage: Re-enter Mr Dornton,

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Your ſervant, gentlemen, your ſervant.—Pray how happens it that you bring your accounts in here

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: We received notice, ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You have none of you any demands upon me?

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Happy to ſerve you ſir,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: We ſhall all be glad of your cuſtom ſir,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All, all!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And do you come expecting to be paid?

sp.speaker: Firſt T,
sp.p: Money, ſir, is always agreeable,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Tradeſmen find it a ſcarce commodity:

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: Bills come round quick,

sp.speaker: Fourth T.
sp.p: Workmen muſt eat!

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: For my part, I always give a gentleman, who is a gentleman▪ his own time.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I underſtand you!—And what are you, ſir, who ſeem to ſtand apart from the reſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſier.
sp.p: A hoſier, ſir, I am unworthy the company of theſe honeſt gentlemen, who live in ſtyle, I never affront a punctual paymaſter▪ not I: and, what they will think ſtrange, I get more by thoſe who do look over their bills, than thoſe who do not,

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Humph! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Blab!

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: Shab!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And what may be the amount of your bill, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A triſle, for which I have no right to aſk,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: No right! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Your ſon, ſir, made me what I am; redeemed me and my family from ruin; and it would be an ill requital of his goodneſs to come here, like a dun, at ſuch a time as this; when I would rather, if that could help him, give him every ſhilling I have in the world,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Would you? Would you? [Greatly affected] You look like an honeſt man! But what do you do here then?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Mr Dornton, ſir, knew I ſhould be unwilling to come, and ſent me word he would never ſpeak to me more if I did not: and, rather than offend him, I would even come here on a buſineſs like this,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Shakes him by the hand] You are an honeſt fellow—! An unaccountable—and ſo Harry has been your friend?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes ſir; a liberal-minded friend; for he lent me money, though I was ſincere enough to tell him of his faults.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Zounds ſir, how came you to be a weaver of ſtockings?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I don't know, ſir, how I came to be at all; I only know that here I am,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A philoſopher!

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I am not fond of titles, ſir—I'm a man,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why is it not a ſhame, now, that the ſoul of Socrates ſhould have crept and hid itſelf in the body of a ſtocking-weaver? give me your bill,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Excuſe me, ſir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Give me your bill, I tell you! I'll pay this bill myſelf:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I cannot, muſt not, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir, I inſiſt on— [Enter Harry Dornton] ſo ſir, [Turning angrily▪ around] why have you aſſembled theſe people into whoſe debt you have diſhoneſtly run, wanting the power to pay; and who have as diſhoneſtly truſted you, hoping to profit exorbitantly by your extravagance?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Oh, fir, you don't know them! They are very complaiſant, indulgent kind of people. Are not you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Firſt T.
sp.p: Certainly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Be kind enough to wait a few minutes without, my good friends. [Exeunt Tradeſmen] Mr, Williams— [Takes his hand]

sp.speaker: Hoſier.
sp.p: Sir— [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How dare you introduce this ſwarm of locuſts here? How dare you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [With continued good humour] Deſpair, ſir, is a dauntleſs hero.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Have you the effrontery to ſuppoſe that I can or ſhall pay them?—What is it you mean?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To let you ſee I have creditors.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Cheats! Bloodſuckers!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Some of them: but that is my fault—They muſt be paid.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Paid!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The innocent muſt not ſuffer for the guilty.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You will die in an alms-houſe!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: May be ſo; but the orphan's and the widow's curſe ſhall not meet me there!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Zounds! [Checking his fondneſs] Paid! Whom do you mean to rob?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My name is Dornton, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you not—? [Wanting words.]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Quit the room! Begone!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
You are the beſt of men, ſir, and I—! But I hate whining. Repentance is a pitiful ſcoundrel, that
never brought▪ back a ſingle yeſterday. Amendment is a fellow of more mettle—But it is too late—Suffer I ought, and ſuffer I muſt—my debts of honour diſcharged, do not let my tradeſmen go unpaid.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You have ruined me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The whole is but five thouſand pounds!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But?—The counter is loaded with the deſtruction you▪ have brought upon us all!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no—I have been a ſad fellow, but not even my extravagance can ſhake this houſe.

div.stage: Enter Mr. SMITH, in conſternation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Bills are pouring in ſo faſt upon us we ſhall never get through!

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: [Struck] What!—What is that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: We have paid our▪light gold ſo often over that the people are very ſurly!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Pay it no more! Sell it inſtantly▪ for what it is worth, diſburſe the laſt guinea, and ſhut up the doors!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Taking Mr, Smith aſide] Are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: Mr, Smith.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Impatiently.] Are you ſerious, I ſay?—Is it not ſome trick to impoſe upon me?

sp.speaker: Mr, Smith.
sp.p: Look into the ſhop, ſir, and convince yourſelf!—If we have not a ſupply in half an hour we muſt ſtop! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Wildly] Tol de rol—My father! Sir! [Turning away] Is it poſſible?—Diſgraced?—Ruined?—In reality ruined?—By me?—Are theſe things ſo?—Tol de rol—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry!—How you look!—You frighten me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Starting] It ſhall be done!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What do you mean?—Calm yourſelf, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay! By heaven!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hear me, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This inſtant! [Going]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling] Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Don't droop! [Returning] Don't deſpair! I'll find relief— [Aſide] firſt to my friend—he cannot fail? But if he ſhould!—why ay, then to Megaera!—I will marry her, in ſuch a cauſe, were ſhe fifty widows, and fifty furies!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Calm yourſelf Harry,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
I am calm! Very calm—it ſhall be done—don't be dejected—You are my father—you were the firſt of men in the firſt of cities—revered by the good and reſpected
by the great—you flouriſhed profperouſly!—But you had a ſon!—I remember it!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why do you roll your eyes Harry,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I won't be long away,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Stay where you are, Harry! [Catching his hand] All will be well, I am very happy, do not leave me,—I am very happy!—indeed I am Harry,—very happy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—heaven bleſs you, ſir! You are a worthy gentleman, I'll not be long:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hear me, Harry—I'm very happy!

div.stage: Enter a Clerk.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Mr Smith, ſir, deſires to know whether we may ſend to the Bank for a thouſand pounds worth of ſilver

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Furiouſly] No ſcoundrel,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling and almoſt ſobbing] Harry,—Harry, I am very happy,—Harry Dornton! [In a kind of ſtupor] I am very happy,—Very happy. [Exit following,

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of Mr SILKY.
Mr SILKY and JACOB.

sp.speaker: Silky.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch not called yet, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: No, ſir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nor any meſſage from the widow?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, ſir, [Knocking heard]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: See who knocks, Jacob, [Exit Jacob] I dare ſay it is one or t'other! They muſt come to me at laſt,

div.stage: Enter Harry Dornton, in wild haſte, following Jacob.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: [Entering] Are you ſure he is at home?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He is here, ſir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Mr Silky, [panting]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah! my dear Mr Dornton, how do you do? I hope you are very well! I am exceedingly glad to ſee you! this call is ſo kind, ſo condeſcending, it gives me infinite pleaſure,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Mr Silky, you muſt inſtantly grant me a favour,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A favour, what is it? How can I ſerve you? I would run to the world's end,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You muſt exert your whole friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Friendſhip, ſir? Say duty, 'twas you that made a man of me! I ſhould have been ruined, in the Bench, I know not where or what, had you not come forward
and ſupported me at the critical moment! And now I can defy the world,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Impatiently] Hear me, I know you can,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh yes! The ſum you lent me, a lucky ſpeculation, five years of continual good fortune, and other little lifts have made me, I won't ſay what—But, your father and perhaps another or two excepted, I ſay perhaps, I'll ſhew my head with the proudeſt of 'em

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why then I am a fortunate man!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: To be ſure you are! how can I ſerve you? what can I do? Make me happy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You can reſcue me from phrenſy!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Can I?—I am proud! Infinitely happy!—What? How? I am a lucky fellow! Tell me which way?—Where can I run? What can I do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Dreading] The requeſt is ſerious—trying!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: So much the better! So much the better! Whom would I ſerve, if not you?—You! The ſon of the firſt man in the city!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Wildly] You miſtake!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I don't! You are, you are! Dornton and Co. may challenge the world, the houſe of Hope perhaps excepted!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Woefully miſtaken!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Our houſe is in danger of ſtopping payment!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir?—Stop payment!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My follies are the cauſe!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have not been uſed to aſk▪favours—but—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Scorn me, curſe me, ſpurn me, but ſave my father!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What means this alteration in your countenance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh dear, no! Ha, ha, ha! Not in the leaſt! Ha, ha, ha! I aſſure you, I, I, I—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have told you our ſituation. Yourſelf and two other friends muſt jointly ſupport my father, by your credit, to the amount of fifty thouſand pounds—Mark me!—Muſt!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand pounds, Mr. Dornton! Fifty thouſand pounds! Are you dreaming? Me? Fifty thouſand pounds! Me? Or half the ſum? Or a fifth of the ſum Me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prevaricating ſcound—! Hear me, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [In fear] Yes, ſir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I muſt be calm— [Burſting out] Are you not a—! I ſay—Sir—You have yourſelf informed me of your ability, and I muſt inſiſt, obſerve ſir! I inſiſt on your immediate performance of this act of duty!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Duty, and fifty thouſand pounds! Are you made Mr. Dornton? Are you mad? Or do you think me mad?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think you the baſeſt of wretches!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Dornton, I would do any thing to ſerve you! Any thing, I proteſt to Heaven!—Would go any where, run—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Of my errands, wipe my ſhoes! Any dirty menial office that coſt you nothing—And this you call ſhewing your gratitude?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is it not, Mr Dornton?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [His anger riſing] And will you give no help to the houſe

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Dornton!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: After the favours you have been for many years receiving, the profeſſions you have been daily making, and the wealth you have by theſe means been hourly acquiring! Will you not, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Retreating] Nay, Mr. Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you not, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't hurt a poor old man! I can't!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Seizing, ſhaking him, and throwing him from him] Scoundrel! [Exit

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Bleſs my heart! Stop payment?—The houſe of Dornton!—Fifty thouſand pounds? I declare I am all of a tremble! James! William!

div.stage: Enter two Clerks.
div.p: Have we any bills on the houſe of Dornton?

sp.speaker: Fr. Cl.
sp.p: I have juſt been examining the books, ſir, We have bills to the amount of—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: How much? How much? A thouſand pounds?

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: Three, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Three!—Three thouſand? Bleſs my heart!

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: We heard the news the very moment after young Mr. Dornton came in!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Run, pay the bills away!

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: Where, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Any where! Any body will take 'em! Run with them to my dear friend, Mr Smallware; it is too far for him to have heard of the craſh. Begone! Don't leave
him Give my very beſt reſpects to him! He will oblige me infinitely! Fly! [Exit Firſt Clerk] And go you, James, to the clearing houſe, and get it whiſpered among the clerks. Then if there are any of Dornton's bills to be bought at fifty per cent. diſcount, let me know. I will buy up all I can— [Exit Clerk] It's a ſafe ſpeculation: I know the houſe: there muſt be a good round dividend. [Exit

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: SCENE I, The Houſe of the Widow WARREN,
Enter JENNY followed by Harry Dornton, who with an oppreſſed heart, but half drunk with wine and paſſion, aſſumes the appearance of wild and exceſſive gaiety.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A WAY, Handmaid of Hecate! Fly!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, you don't mean as you ſay!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you begone, Cerberea?—Invite my Goddeſs to deſcend in a golden ſhower, and ſuddently relieve theſe racking doubts.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.q: Goddeſs!—I knew you meant miſs Sophy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.q: Prime tormentrix to the Furies, begone!

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.q: What, ſir, to my old Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.q: Hear you?—Yes! I want an old Miſtreſs, with her old gold, inſtantly to relieve an injured old man—Tol de rol—Vaniſh, daughter of Nox! Tell her what a gay and love ſick humour I am in—Tol de rol.

div.stage: Enter WIDOW, and Exit JENNY diſſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Smiling] Mr. Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Widow!—Here am I!—Phaeton the ſecond hurled from my flaming car! I come burning with fierce deſires, devoutly bent on committing the deadly ſin of matrimony! May theſe things be? Speak, my ſaving Angel!

p.q: Fie upon you! How can you throw one into ſuch inſuperable trepidation of ſpirits?
Will you have me?—Pronounce but the bleſſed Yes, and I am thine for ever and for aye.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.q:
Ay, ay—I know very well—The formal No, the crimſon bluſh, the half-conſenting ſide-glance, the
heſitating Yes, the palpitation violent—We'll ſuppoſe them all—There, there!—I have acted them over, and parſon's tragical farce is going to begin!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, but—! Dear Mr Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not imagine, amiable widow, that I am mad!—No, no, no!— [With a hyſteric laugh] Only a little flighty—Left my father furiouſly, drank three bottles of Burgundy franticly, flew in amorous phrenſy to the attack, and will carry the place or die on the ſpot!—Powder and poiſon await my choice; and let me tell you, ſweet widow, I am a man of my word. So you'll have me, won't you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, Mr Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why you would not ſee my father periſh! Would you? And me expire! Would you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Am I ſo very cruel?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then ſay Yes!—Yes or—Piſtols—Daggers—Cannon balls!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, yes, yes!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hold, fair widow! Kind widow, hold! Be not raſh!—I am the verieſt! villain!—Avoid me!—A ruined—! But that were indeed a trifle—My father! Him! Him have I ruined! Heard you that? Bring forth your hoards! Let him once more be himſelf, and bid me kiſs the duſt!

p.q: Elegant youth! [Aloud] Ah you flatterer! I own you have been a little—wild, but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.q: A little! Oh! Ha, ha, ha! Widow. I am a ſad fellow!—A damned ſad dog!—I tell you I have ruined my father—A prince of fathers! Who, had I not been a raſcal, would have given me his ſoul! And I have ruined him!—Ruined him!—Beware of me!—Fly me!—Yet ſhould you?—Riſe Imps of night! Deep have I ſworn to find ſome means to ſave a father from deſtruction, and I will keep my oath though—!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh fie! How can you terrify one ſo?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And wilt thou, widow, be his ſupport? [Eagerly] Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel queſtion! How can I deny?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Immortal bleſſings be upon thee! My father!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will be all rapture to hear—!

p.q:
Will he?—Words of comfort!—Will he?—A buxom, fair and bounteous dame, whoſe treaſures
can reſtore his tottering fortunes to their wonted ſplendour! Ha! Will he? Will he?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.q: Certainly, Mr. Dornton, he cannot be diſpleaſed at ſuch a choice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Shakes his head] Ah, ha, ha, ha, [Sighs] You don't know my father! A ſtrange, affectionate—! That loves me—! Oh! He—! And you ſee how I uſe him! You ſee how I uſe him! But no matter—Tol de rol—We'll be married to-night.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh fie!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay, my Madona! To-night's the day—The ſooner the better—'Tis to reſcue a father, blithſome widow! A father! To ſave him have I fallen in love—Remember—Sin with open eyes, widow—Money—I muſt have money—Early in the morn, ere counters echo with the ring of gold, fifty thouſand muſt be raiſed!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It ſhall, Mr. Dornton.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, ſhall it? Shall it? Speak again, beatific viſion, ſpeak! Shall it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—He ſhall live! He ſhall ſmile! Again his heart ſhall feel joy!—Oh my bland and bonny widow! [Partly ſinging] My widow fair and debonair—Keep thy word—Let but my father be himſelf, and I am thine! Body and ſoul thine!

p.q: And are your really—? Oh, no!—No— [Coquettiſhly] You are not in love?

q.l: And we'll love by day, and we'll live by night—
With a hey and a ho and a heigho, widow!
I have drunk Burgundy—To your health, auſpicious Amazon!—Burgundy!

lg.l: For I wanted the grace [Sings▪
Of a bold villain's face,
To prevail, with heigho,
On a buxom widow. [Kiſſes her

p.q: [Coquetting] Fie! I ſhall hate you, if you are ſo fond of me! I ſhall indeed!—But no—You are man!—Roving faithleſs man!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no! Fear not! Thou, gracious widow, art my overflowing cup of conſolation—What! A father ſaved—?—Remember!—Fifty thouſand the firſt thing in the morning?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And would not a part this evening—?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Suddenly] What ſayeſt thou?—Oh, no!—Whoo!—Thouſands—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: "No: you are a naughty bad man, and I don't love you: I don't indeed—Elſe." I have a trifling ſum.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Eagerly] How much?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Six thouſand—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Six?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which I meant to have diſpoſed of, but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no! I'll diſpoſe of it, dear widow! [Kiſſes her] I'll diſpoſe of it in a twinkling! [Elated] Thou▪art my Goddeſs! [Kiſſes her again] By the faith of my body but I will thank thee—Yea thee will love exceedingly!

p.q: Will I? [Sighs] Shall I not be in duty bound?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My fair Pelican of Potoſi! Queen of Pactolus! Doubt not my gratitude—Let this and this— [Kiſſing

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie! You are a ſad man—But I'll bring you a draft!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do, my blooming widow! Empreſs of the golden iſles, do

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I tell you, you are a very bad man!—But remember, this trifle is for your own uſe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, my pearl unparalleled! My father's! My father's! My pocket is an inſidious gulf, into which I never more will guineas caſt. Save but my father, and I will kiſs the ground on which thou treadeſt, and live and breathe but on thy bounty! [Self-indignation.]
sp.l: At leaſt till time and fate ſhall means afford
Somewhat to perform, worthy of man and me.

div.stage: Enter JENNY peeping.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: St!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ah, ha! my merry maid of May!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you are waiting to ſee miſs Sophy, now you have got rid of the old lady?

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p:
Got rid of the old lady?—Thou brazen pinplacer, thou virgin of nine-and-twenty years occupation! No. "I have not got rid of the old lady▪"
The old lady is to be my blooming, youthful bride!—And I, happy youth, am written and deſtined in the records of eternity her other half!—"Before the ſtars were this marriage was decreed—" Heigho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, what rapturation,—But ſtay a little, and I'll tell miſs Sophy her mamma wants her, here; ſo then—huſh— [Jenny retires, making a ſign, and

div.stage: Re-enter the Widow Warren.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: "An't you a ſad man?"—Here's the draft,

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Thanks, my Sultana—Thou ſhall find me very grateful—Thou haſt bought and paid for me, and I am thine!—By fair and honeſt traffic thine!—This halcyon night the prieſt, pronouncing conjurations dire,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, I won't look at you:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay, to-night we'll marry; ſhall we not?

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: I'll not anſwer you a word! [Enter Sophia ſkippingly, but ſtops ſhort,] "You are a dangerous man" [Sitting down and coquetting] how dare you talk to me of to-night?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To-night ſhall be a night of wonder, and we'll love like— [Aſide] like Darby and Joan,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Languiſhing] I ſhall hate you intolerably!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hey for the parſon's permiſſion, hay my ſublime widow,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To ſteal thus upon one at an unguarded moment—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But here firſt let me kneel, and thus to Ceres pay [Going to kiſs her hand in rapture, meets the eye of Sophia,]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: "I'll never forgive you!—I hate you now worſe than ever."

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Coming between them with burſting trepidation, taking the valentine from her boſom and preſenting it] there ſir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: There ſir,—Oh pray ſir, take it ſir,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why minikin—I

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I requeſt ſir,—I deſire ſir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Declining it] Tol de rol,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Tearing the paper piecemeal, and throwing it ſpitefully away] why then there, ſir—and there, ſir—and there, there, there, there, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor minikin! I declare, ſhe is jealous,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Her ſobs riſing] And I'll—I'll—wri-i-i-ite to my—to my grandma-a-a-a directly,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, child,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And I'll go do-o-o-own—into Glo-o-o-oſterſhire,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go up to your chamber, child!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And I'll tell▪my grandma-a what a falſe, baſe, bad man you are: and ſhe ſhall ha-ate you, and deſpiſe you; and every body ſhall ha-ate you, and deſpiſe you; and I'll ha-a-ate you, and deſpiſe you myſelf!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor thing!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And moreover I'll hate and deſpiſe all mankind and for your ſake [with great energy] I'll live and die a maid!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, child, that I dare be ſworn you will,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Widow, I'm a ſad fellow, don't have me—I'm a vile fellow, Sophy! You are right to deſpiſe me, I am going to marry your mother!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I'll go down into Glo-o-oſterſhire—I wo-on't live in ſuch a falſe-hearted city! And you ought to be aſhamed of yourſelf, ma', to make yourſelf ſo ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no, ſweet Slyth, it is my fault, all my fault!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Enraged] Be gone, miſs!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Interpoſing] Sweet widow! gentle widow,—I've ſold myſelf, Sophy, ſix thouſand pounds is the earneſt money paid down, for the reptile Harry Dornton—I love you, Sophy!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How, Mr Dornton?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I do by heaven! Take back your money, widow [Offering the draft] I'm a ſad ſcoundrel,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You are a baſe faithleſs man, you know you are, and you are a pitileſs woman, a mercileſs woman, for all you are my own mother, to let my poor brother Milford go to be ſtarved to death in a dark dungeon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Milford in priſon?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, arreſted by your cruel, old, ugly father, I'm ſure he is ugly! Though I never ſaw him in my life, I'm ſure he is an ugly, hideous, ugly monſter! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Is this true, widow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Stammering] ſir—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Agitated] Arreſted by my father?—ſquandering her money on a ruined reprobate, and won't releaſe her huſband's ſon?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but, dear Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I'll be with you again preſently, widow; preſently, preſently, [Exit.

div.stage: Enter JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch is coming up ma'am,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have no time to waſte with Mr Goldfinch. I'll preſently ſend him about his buſineſs. Mr Dornton talks I don't know how Jenny—ſays it muſt be tonight—

div.stage: Enter GOLDFINCH.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well widow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not ſo free, ſir! [walks up the ſtage diſdainfully]

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide to Goldfinch] Have you got the licence?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No—Been to Tatterſall's,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And not for the licence?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee I've been to Tatterſall's,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ah, It's all over!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Made ſure of the eclipſe colts—muſt not loſe 'em,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide] Stupid boody!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Advancing] what is your preſent buſineſs ſir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My buſineſs, ha, ha, ha! That's a good one▪ I'll tell you my buſineſs, [Approaching with open arms]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Haughtily] Keep your diſtance ſir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Diſtance, widow? No; that's not the way, I ſhould be double diſtanced if I did.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Were you indeed a man of deportment and breeding!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Breeding? look at my ſpurs,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Had you the manner, the ſpirit, the—But no—You are no gentleman—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Whew! No gentleman? [Claps on his hat and takes a lounging impudent ſwagger] Dammee that's a good one!—Charles Goldfinch no gentleman?—Aſk in the box-lobby! Enquire at the ſchool! [In a boxing attitude.]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, you are a tedious perſon: your company is troubleſome!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Turf or turnpike, keep the beſt of cattle—Walk, trot or gallop—Run, amble or canter—Laugh at every thing on the road—Give 'em all the go-by—Beat the trotting butcher! Gentleman?—That's is your ſort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide to Goldfinch.] Follow me. [Exit

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I beg, ſir, I may not be intruded upon with you or your horſe-jockey jargon any more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here's a kick up. What's all this? Muſt have her or ſmaſh!—Smirker [Pointing after Jenny] will tell me what it means!—Smart thing for a light weight. Spirit, ſhape, and form—Carry a fine neck in a running martingale—Shews blood—Win all the give and takes—Take her into training—Match her the Abingdon mile againſt all England—That's your ſort! [Exit.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at the Houſe of a Sheriff's Officer.
Enter HARRY DORNTON in the ſame hurry and Officer.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Diſpatch, man! Diſpatch! Tell Jack Milford I can't wait a moment! Hold—Write an acquittal inſtantly for the thouſand pounds. But ſay not a word to him of my intention!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: A thouſand, ſir? It is almoſt five thouſand!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: There are detainders already lodged to that amount.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Five thouſand?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Muſt I write the acquittal for the ſum total?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No—Yes, write it however. Have it ready. Early to-morrow morning it ſhall be paid.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: In the mean time there may be more detainders.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Damnation! What ſhall I do?—Run, ſend him! And do you here, a bottle of Champaign and two rummers!—Rummers! Mind!—Not a word to him!— [Exit Officer] Five thouſand?—And more detainders!

div.stage: Enter WAITER with bottle and glaſſes, and MILFORD following.

sp.speaker: Milford.
sp.p: Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How now, Jack! What's your wonder? I can't ſtay a moment with you, but I could not paſs without giving you a call. Your hand, my boy! Cheer up!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Excuſe me, ſir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Why, Jack!—Pſhaw! Caſt away this gloom and be—Honeſt Jack Milford! You are now in tribulation;
what of that? Why, man, the bleſſed ſu • himſelf is ſometimes under a cloud! Wait but till tomorrow—Where is this wine?— [Fills the rummers] Come, drink, and waſh away grief! 'Sblood, never look froſty and aſkaunce, man, but drink, drink, drink!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Abruptly] Sir? I am not diſpoſed to drink!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "Why what a tabernacle phraſe is that!" Here's confuſion to all ſorrow and thinking!—I could a tale unfold—! But I won't afflict you—I muſt fly—Yet I can do no good to-night— Hurrah, Jack! Keep up your ſpirits! Be determined, like me!—I am the vileſt of animals that crawl the earth—Yet I won't flag!—I'll die a bold face villain! I have ſold myſelf—Am diſinherited—Have loſt—Ah, Sophia!—Hurrah, Jack!—Keep it up!—Round let the great globe whirl; and whirl it will, though I ſhould happen to ſlide from its ſurface into infinite nothingneſs—Drink, my noble ſoul!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Your mirth is impertinent, ſir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: So it is, Jack!—Damned impertinent! But ruin is around us, and it is high time to be merry!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Sir? I muſt inform you that, though I have been betrayed by you and impriſoned by your father, I will not be inſulted!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Betrayed by me?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ay, ſir! I have had full information of your mean arts! It was neceſſary I ſhould be out of the way, that your deſigns on Mrs. Warren might meet no interruption!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—Good day, Jack, good day!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, inform your father I deſpiſe his meanneſs, and ſpurn at his malice!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Suddenly returning and darting on him, but ſtopping ſhort] Jack Milford!—Utter no blaſphemy againſt my father!—I am half mad!—I came your friend.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I deſpiſe your friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That as you pleaſe—Think all that is vile of me I defy you to exceed the truth—But utter not a word againſt my father!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Deliberately, pitifully malignant!—Not ſatisfied with the little vengeance he himſelf could take, he has ſent round to all my creditors!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Falſe?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A vile, eternal falſehood!

div.stage: Enter OFFICER with papers and writs,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Gentlemen!—Did you call?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Interrupting him] Leave the room, ſir!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: But—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: We are buſy, ſir!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I thought—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I tell you we are buſy, and muſt not be interrupted! [Exit Offcer] [Pauſe of conſideratiou] Mr. Milford, you ſhall hear from me immediately.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [After ruminating] What were thoſe papers? Surely I have not been raſh?—Nobody but his father could have brought my creditors thus on me all at once?—He ſeemed half drunk or half frantic!—Said he was ruined, diſinherited—Talked ſomething of to-morrow—What could the purport of his coming be? [Enter Officer] Well, ſir?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Here is a note, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: The young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Reads aſide] 'I underſtand you are liberty'—How! At liberty? [The Officer bows] [Reads] I ſhall walk up to Hyde Park: you will find me at the Ring at ſix—Exactly at ſix'—At liberty?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Your debts are all diſchared.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Impoſſible!—Which way?—By whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Why, ſir—That is—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No heſitation, but tell me by whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Sir—I thought I perceived ſome anger between you and the young gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Aſk no queſtions, ſir; make no delays! Tell me who has paid my debts?—Tell me the truth—Conſequences you do not ſuſpect depend upon your anſwer!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I perceive, ſir, there has been ſome warmth between you: and though the young gentleman made me promiſe ſilence and ſecrecy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Aſtoniſhment] What then it was Mr. Dornton? [Officer bows] Madman! What have I done! [Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of DORNTON.
Enter HARRY DORNTON, followed by Mr. SMITH.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And the danger not yet paſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Far from it! Mr. Sulky has twice brought us ſupplies, and is gone a third time.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Brave ſpirit! He would coin his heart!—My father ſupports it nobly?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He is anxious only for you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well▪ well! Ha▪ ha, ha! Tol lol—I'll bring him relief—Comfort him, aſſure him of it!—Ay, hear me heaven and—! To-night it is too late, but to-morrow all ſhall be well!—Excellent well!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: [Significantly] You will marry the widow?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Have you heard?—Ay, boy, ay!—We'll marry! "I will go and prepare her—We'll marry!"—Early in the morning that all may be ſafe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "I have told her the truth. She knows all: knows what a vile infernal—I tell you ſhe knows me! My father again ſhall look upon the glare of the day! Firſt to the proctor, next to the lawyer, and then—! Ha, ha, ha! Ay then to my fair bride! Heareſt thou, my noble ſoul? I ſay my bride! My fair, my blooming, thrice-bedded bride! No novice ſhe, old true blue! Tol de rol—It will be a merry wedding! Conſole my father! Cheer him! Enlighten his ſoul with hope! I'll keep my word; What, does he not know me? Am I not his own ſon?—Why, ay— [Looking at his watch] The proctor's, the lawyer's, the widow's, and [Starts] at ſix?— [Aſide] The Ring?—The Ring at ſix? Fiends!—Who can ſay what may happen?—What, leave my father to periſh?—I'll not go! Though all hell ſhould brand me for a coward, I'll not go!—Mr. Smith, take care of my father!—Mark me, I recommend my father to you! [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mr. DORNTON

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Where is Harry?—Did not I hear his voice?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He is this moment gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Gone where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Do you not ſuſpect where, ſir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Suſpect!—What?—Speak?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: To the widow Warren's.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: To marry her.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Marry!—The widow Warren!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: And ſave the houſe by her fortune.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Generous Harry! Noble affectionate boy! I'd periſh firſt!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He ſeems very reſolute—He has already had ſix thouſand pounds of her.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Marry her? I ſhall go mad!—Where is Mr. Sulky?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He is juſt returned, I hear him in the compting-houſe,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Tell him I wiſh to ſpeak with him, [Exit Mr Smith] Harry Dornton and the widow Warren? I ſhall die in Bedlam! [Enter Mr Sulky] Are we ſafe, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: For to-day, perhaps,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What bank have we to begin to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can't tell—I fear not thirty thouſand.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky, you—you—have this day ſhewn yourſelf an active partner, and a ſincere friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I have long eſteemed you; I eſteem you more and more,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: My ſon Harry— [Heſitating] You are a very good man, Mr Sulky; a compaſſionate man, though you don't look ſo,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to ſee ſo noble a youth—I am ſure you would not wiſh him any harm, Mr Sulky, I am ſure you would not!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry Dornton, would you—would you—would you, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: A kind queſtion,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Nay, I did not mean to be unkind, Mr Sulky, you know I did not—ſhall we not venture one ſtep more to ſave him?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Save? Impoſſible! Ruin only can reform him▪ total ruin.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You miſtake, Mr Sulky, his own misfortunes little affected him, but mine—he is ſtruck to the heart—I know him▪

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: Struck to the heart—I'm ſure on't! he'll be a good man!—A great man,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You know the widow Warren, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Don't you?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I never ſaw her in my life—I hear ſhe is full forty, her manners abſurd, her character cruel, and her morals—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Bad enough,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Six thouſand pounds at this moment is a great ſum! I own it! But do you think I ought not to venture?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Venture what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: To—To take it from our bank?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For—For the—the relief of Harry Dornton?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, take all! what is it to me?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Nay, but, Mr Sulky, you ſurely don't ſee the thing in the right light?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can ſtarve, like the reſt!

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: [Snappiſh haſte] Very well▪ Mr Sulky, very well: I perceive you can be intereſted, and—and—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, Mr Sulky, very well!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can ſtare bankruptcy in the face as ſtedfaſtly as you can.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ay, ay. No doubt! The world is all alike! I am an old fool, and ſo ſhall live and die:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Why do you aſk my advice? Take the money. Empty the coffers! Pour it all into his hat, give him guineas to play at chuck farthing, and bank bills to curl his hair.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, Mr Sulky:—Friendſhip, generoſity, a ſenſe of juſtice. Oh, it's all a farce,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Rings] Very well, ſir: Very well, [Enter ſervant] Is the carriage ready?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: It's at the door, ſir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Going▪ turns back] So, Mr Sulky, you could ſee him married to this widow, to whom you have ſo often as well as now given the worſt of character, rather than incur a little more riſk for your friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Marry?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes, marry,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The widow Warren, I tell you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And Harry Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes, and Harry Dornton,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: When, where?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Immediately, with unexampled affection, to ſave me who am old and worthleſs, he would devote his youth, his great quailities, and his noble heart, to all the torments which ſuch a marriage and ſuch a woman can inflict

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Take the money!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you ſerious, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Take the money, away, begone! I would indeed ſtarve, inchmeal, rather than he ſhould marry her,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky, you are a worthy man, a true friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Curſe compliments, make haſte. [Exeunt

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: SCENE The Widow WARREN'S, SOPHIA and JENNY meeting.

sp.speaker: JENNY.
sp.p: So, miſs! here's your mamma juſt coming down,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Much agitated] Is ſhe dreſſed?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh yes!—I have decorationed her out like any king's coach horſe,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: With her ribbands and ringlets ſtuck about and dangle-ating down her back and all here—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Tight laced—"Thomas called up to help."—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's all very well!—But it will be no wedding,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aſide] I hope not;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: He told her to her face that he loved me, and offered to give her the money back—He'll never have her—And if he does I don't care—I know I ſhall die broken-hearted, but I don't care—I'll tell all to my dear grandma', for I'll not ſtay in this wicked city—No i he ſhan't ſee me pine away—I know my ghoſt will haunt him; but I can't help it. I never wiſhed him any harm, and had he but been true-hearted and have waited for me, I would—But it's no matter—He ſhan't ſee a tear that I ſhed, nor hear the leaſt ſigh that I heave.

div.stage: Enter the Widow WARREN.

sp.speaker: Jen:
sp.p: [Looking, admiring, and walking round her] Well, ma'am—! I declare you're a pictur!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you think I look tolerably, Jenny? [Walking and ſurveying herſelf]—Shall I do execution? What is the matter, child?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Mark my words, he'll never have you!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor thing!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: He never will!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Run, Jenny, ſee who it is! [Exit Jenny] Go up to your chamber, child.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No! I will ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Begone to your chamber, I ſay, miſs!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Beat me if you pleaſe, kill me, but I will not!

div.stage: Re-enter JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here's an elderly gentleman, ma'am, aſks to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you begone, miſs?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Since it is not he I don't want to ſtay. I only want to look him in the face once more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is he dreſſed?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: In grey ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In gray? [Conſidering.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In d •• k gr • y? [Hoping.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Earneſtly] Does he look like a parſon, Jenny?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why ma'am he is a ſoberly, ſnug, jobationlooking man enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let him be ſhewn in—I dare ſay it is the Divine!

div.stage: Footman introduces Mr. DORNTON.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir your very moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I preſume you are unacquainted with me?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Simpering] I believe I can penetrate, ſir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Can you, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [With her fan before her face] You—You come on the—part of—young Mr. Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Surpriſed] I do!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Aſide] It is the parſon!—Would you be ſo indulgent as to be ſeated, ſir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Excuſe me, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Would you be pleaſed to take any refreſhment, fir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Madam?—None, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A morſel of ſeed-cake, a French biſcuit, a bit of orange-loaf, a glaſs of Conſtantia, or a jelly?—I know theſe little cordial comforts are agreeable conſolations to gentlemen of your cloth.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Surveying himſelf] Cloth!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No offence, I hope? I participate in them myſelf.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hem! No doubt!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are acquainted with Mr. Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why—Yes—I am I believe one of his oldeſt acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then I dare ſay you have a great regard for him?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hem!—Yes—I—had a—ſort of a friendſhip for him even before he was born.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir!—Oh!—You are intimate With the family?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes—yes, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And know his father?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Um— [Shrugs] Why—Though I have kept him company from the day of his birth to this very hour, they tell me I don't know him yet!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ay indeed, is he ſo odd▪

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sometimes—To my great regret, I have ſometimes found him a very abſurd old gentleman,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it—Becauſe as I am ſoon to become—hymeneally—his intimate—relation—I—I—!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You would wiſh for a ſenſible indulgent—Papa— [Smiles.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It's natural ſir, [Simpering.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ha, I dare not ſay too much in his favour,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay though I have a vaſt—hum—ha—regard for young Mr Dornton—I own I have no great predilection of opinion for the father!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Suddenly] Nor he for you, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I am ſure ſo!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant, ſir, he is, as you ſay, a very preciſe acrimonious perſon—A tetchy repugnant kind of old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I ſaid no ſuch thing, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah! a little caution, ſir, to be ſure, becomes gentlemen of your cloth,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p:
Cloth again!—I don't know what you mean
by my cloth: but Mr Dornton, madam, is little older than yourſelf: nor does he think himſelf half ſo repugnant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Recollecting himſelf] Madam—I—I beg your pardon,—I— [Bowing.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Knocking heard] Oh! here I dare comes the bridegroom, [Enraptured, croſſes to the door.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Aſide] My curſt vivacity! I can never tell her after this who I am. [Walks up the ſtage.

div.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON, in haſte.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh you rover,

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, my kind widow! [Mr Dornton turns quick round at hearing his Son's voice, and gradually approaches] My loving compaſſionate widow! I am come poſt haſte to caſt myſelf once more on your bounty,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hu-ſh!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To intreat inſtant commiſeration, and aid,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hem, hem! [Aloud.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have not a minute to ſpare!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Whiſper] He's here, he's come! A waſpiſh, tetchy—! Hem— [Aloud] Your friend has been here ſome time, Mr Dornton.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My friend, what friend?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your friend the clergyman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Clergyman—You— [Turning, ſees his Father at his elbow]—My father!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: His father, [Pauſe.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Well, Harry, why do you look ſo blank? I am glad you are here—Your coming, and the mutual ſincerity with which this lady and I have juſt ſpoken, our ſentiments, will ſave all circumlocution—At preſent we underſtand each other.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Oh, madam, never retract—Let us continue the like plain honeſt dealing—

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: But—ſir—Mr Dornton's affection—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Affection, madam!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry—I know your motives, will never forget them! But the cauſe of them has ceaſed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir?—Beware! No falſe compaſſion! Remember not the vile reprobate that was your ſon! I ſpurn at exiſtence that his coupled with your miſery!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! our danger his over.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Are you—? Are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky is a worthy man! his rich uncle is dead, and has left him ſole heir. Our books too have been examined, and exceed our beſt hopes,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Here is your money, madam.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father ſaved—Tol de rol!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but—Mr Dornton,—ſir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I muſt beg you'll take it—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Rejoice widow! Rejoice! ſing, ſhout! Tol de rol!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I do not want the money, ſir! Filthy money— [Wimpering reſtrained] And as to what I ſaid, though you have arreſted Mr Milford—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha! [ſtarts, conſiders, and looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am ſorry—I beg your pardon—And if Mr Dornton—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak, Harry? Where are you going? [Harry Dornton croſſes haſtily to the door] Come back, Harry!—ſtay, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay!—I muſt fly—My honour is at ſtake, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Alarmed] His honour,—his honour at ſtake! here, here, madam!— [Offering her Bank bills.]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, ſir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, madam, take your money, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel—uſage!—Faithleſs—men—Blind—ſtupid! I'll forſake and forſwear the whole ſex!

div.stage: Enter JENNY with glee on tip-toe, as if ſhe had been on the watch.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Sobbing] Savage race,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ma'am, ma'am! Mr Goldfinch, ma'am

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hay! Mr Goldfinch?—was that what you ſaid, Jenny? [Brightens up] Where?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Below, ma'am. I perſuaded him to come up, but he is quite ſurly,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh! he is coming, well! I think I will ſee him—Yes—I think I will,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I always told you, ma'am, Mr Goldfinch for me,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: But he ſays he will have your written promiſe this very night, or never ſpeak to you more—I hear him. [Adjuſting the widow's dreſs] Law. ma'am, you had better give a few touches—hereabout! Your eyes will have double the ſpirit and fire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will they? [Exit.

div.stage: Enter GOLDFINCH.

sp.speaker: Goldfinch.
sp.p: Where's the Dowager?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Huſh! mind what I ſaid to you—It is too late now for a licence, ſo be ſure get the promiſe—Don't flinch—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Me flinch? Game to the back-bone!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Huſh,

div.stage: Re-enter the Widow WARREN.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here I am once more, widow,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah, rambler!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Are you cured of the tantarums?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Goldfinch—!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Muſt I keep my diſtance?

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Unkind!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Am I a gentleman now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Killing!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Look you, widow, I know your tricks—Skittiſh! Won't anſwer the whip! Run out of the courſe! Take the reſt!—So give me your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My promiſe—!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Signed and ſealed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Naughty man—You ſhan't—I won't let you tyrannize over a palpitating heart!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Palpi— [To Jenny] What does ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You ſhan't ſteal on hymeneal tranſports!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Connubial ecſtaſies!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nu—What?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go, intruder!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh! What you won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll never forgive you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel man!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch! [Calling]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You ſhall have the promiſe!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh, ho! Why then I pull up—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Barbarous youth! Could you leave me?—But I muſt ſend to Mr Silky.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No, no! Let me have the promiſe directly! I'll go myſelf to Silky.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you. Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will I not?—Take a hack, mount the box—Hayait!—Scud away for the old ſcoundrel! I'm a deep one! Know the courſe every inch! I'm the lad for a widow! That's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Saucy man! I'll be very angry with you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Soon be back!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Adieu! Fly ſwiftly, ye minutes!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But I muſt have the promiſe firſt!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will go and write it—Come, diſſembler, come!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: She's an old courſer! But I know I ſhould take her at the double!

div.stage: Enter MILFORD.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: So, Charles, where's the widow?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The widow's mine!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yours?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm the lad! All's concluded—Going poſt for old Silky. [Offers to go at every ſpeech, but is eagerly ſtopped by Milford.]

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Silky did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Am to pay the miſerly raſcal fifty thouſand pounds down! But mum! That's a ſecret!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You are raving!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee he has her on the hip! She can't marry without his conſent!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Don't know. The cloſe old rogue won't tell. Has got ſome deed, he ſays—Some writing.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
Yes—But it's all huſh! I ſhall be a higher fellow than ever, Jack! Go to the ſecond ſpring meeting—Take you with me—Come down a few to the Sweaters and Trainers—The knowing ones—The Lads—Got into
the ſecret—Lay it on thick—Seven hundred to five Favourite againſt the field!—Done!—I'll do it again!—Done!—Five times over ditto repeated!—Done, done! Off they go!—Winner lays by—Pretends to want foot—Odds riſe high! Take 'em—Winner whiſpered lame—Lags after—Odds higher and higher!—Take 'em—Creeps up—Breathes 'em over the flat—Works 'em up hill—Paſſes the diſtance poſt—Still only ſecond—Betting chair in an uproar!—Neck to neck!—Lets him out—Shews him the Whip!—Shoots by like an arrow—Oh dammee a hollow thing!—That's your fort! [Exit

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand to Silky for his conſent becauſe of ſome deed, ſome writing?—If it ſhould be the—? It muſt!—By heaven it muſt! [Exit haſtily.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Ring in Hyde Park.
HARRY DORNTON, looking at his watch.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How long muſt I wait?—I ſee nothing of Milford—I'll cut off that bailiff's ears if he have betrayed me. [Walks about.]

div.stage: Enter Mr. DORNTON, out of breath.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father again!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Panting] What do you do here, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—I—I want air.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So do I—A pretty dance you have led me—What brought you hither?— [Sudden recollection] Where's the money you had of the widow? [Pauſe ſeeming to dread an anſwer] Where's the money, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Reluctantly] Gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Moſt of it.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And your creditors not paid? [Another pauſe] And your creditors not paid?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No▪ ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Raiſes his hands] I ſuſpected—I foreboded this! [Harry Dornton walks up the ſtage] He has been at ſome gaming houſe, loſt all, quarrelled and came here to put a miſerable end to a miſerable exiſtence! Oh, who would be a father! [Extreme anguiſh]

div.stage: Enter Waiter.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p:
I am ſent on an April-day kind of errand here. I think this is what they call the Ring [Look round.]
Hey! Who is this? [Surveying Mr Dornton] Pray—Sir—Is your name Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Wai.
sp.p: Then I am right—Mr Milford, ſir, has ſent me this note.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Advancing] It is for me, ſir!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How do you know, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, I am certain!—I muſt beg—!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: This is no time for ceremony! [Reads] Dear Harry, forgive the provocation I have given you; forget the wrong I have done your father—Me!—I will ſubmit to any diſgrace rather than lift my hand againſt your life—I would have come and apologiſed even on my knees, but I am prevented—J. Milford. [Stands a moment crumbling up the letter]—Why Harry!—What! What is this?—Tell me—Tell me—Is it in paying Milford's debts you have expended the money?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It is, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [After raiſing his claſped hands in rapture as if to return thanks, ſuddenly ſuppreſſes his feelings] But how had he wronged me?—Why did you come here to fight him?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—He—he ſpoke diſreſpectfully of you.

div.stage: [Pauſe.]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [With his eyes fixed on his ſon, till unable any longer to contain himſelf he covers them with one hand and ſtretches out the other] Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Taking his father's hand, but turning his back likewiſe to conceal his agitation] My father! [Pauſe]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Harry! [Struggling affection] [Pauſe]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear ſir, let us fly to conſole poor Milford!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What you will, Harry! Do with me what you will—Oh who would not be a father [Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Houſe of the Widow Warren.
Enter MILFORD and Mr SULKY.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The fool Go ldfinch himſelf informed me, ſir, that Silky is to receive fifty thouſand pounds for his conſent!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand! Zounds! Why then the old ſcoundrel muſt have got poſſeſſion of the will.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p:
Which is ind ubitably meant to be deſtroyed. Goldfinch is juſt returned with Silky. They are now with
the widow, all in high glee, and are coming up here immediately, no doubt to ſettle the buſineſs in private.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: We muſt hide ourſelves ſomewhere, and ſpring upon them.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I hate hiding! It's deceit, and deceit is the reſource of a raſcal.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But there is no avoiding it! We cannot get legal aſſiſtance in time! Here are two cloſets! Do you go into one, and I'll ſhut myſelf up in the other. We ſhall hear what they are about, and can burſt upon them at the proper moment.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well, if it muſt be ſo—But it's a vile, paltry refuge!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I hear them coming! Make haſte!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Sulky and Milford into the cloſets.

div.stage: Enter SILKY, WIDOW, and GOLDFINCH.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I told you, madam, I ſhould hear from you when you wanted me! I knew it muſt come to that! But you are a lucky man. Mr Goldfinch, and I'am a lucky man! ay and you are a lucky woman too, madam! We are all in luck!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay dammee, old one, you have been concerned in many a good thing in your time!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha, ha! To be ſure I have! I muſt provide for my family, Mr. Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is indeed a fortunate event! Do you not participate my raptures, Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be ſure—It's a deep ſcheme! It's knowing a thing or two! Hay, old one? Pigeoning the Green horns!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: All ſo ſafe too, ſo ſnug! I am ſo pleaſed, and ſo happy! It's all our own! Not a ſoul will know of it but our three ſelves!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh yes—One more, old one—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Ay! Who? Who?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your father—Beelzebub!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord! Mr Goldfinch, don't terrify me!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To be ſure, it muſt be owned you are a ſhocking old rogue, Mr Silky! But there is no doing without you—So make haſte with your deeds and your extortions; for really we ſhould be glad to be rid of your company—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, well, I'm ready—I'll not long interrupt your amorous haſte. I am a man of buſineſs! I expected how it would be, and have a legal inſtrument here, ready drawn up by my own hand; which, when it is ſigned and ſealed, will make all ſafe!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But where is the will?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh I have it—Firſt however let us be ſecure. [Locks both the chamber doors: is going to read, but looks round, ſees the cloſet doors, and with great anxiety and cunning locks them too.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You're an old trader in ſin! There's no being too deep for you!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha! Do you think ſo, Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But I ſhould like to ſee you on your death-bed!
sp.stage: [A blow from one of the cloſets.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul!—What's that?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Zounds! Odd enough! I believe he's coming for you before your time!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It was very ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I declare I am all of a tremble!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, come, let us get the ſhocking buſineſs over!—Where is the will?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Don't ſhake ſo man!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, well!—Firſt ſign the bond! [Widow and Goldfinch going to ſign, another knock heard] Lord have mercy upon me!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I ſmell ſulpher!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Save me, Mr Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The candles burn blue! [Pauſe

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Zounds, it is only ſome cat in the cloſet!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I heard it in both the cloſets!

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: Why then there are two cats!—Come! I'll ſign—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Where's the promiſe?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here it is! [Laying it on the table

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And here is the will, which, that all may be ſafe, we will immediately commit to the flames. [Is going to burn it at the candle. Four ſucceſſive loud knocks are heard, one from each of the doors. Silky ſtarts, drops one candle, and overturns the other. T • e ſtage dark,]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord have mercy upon us!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My hair ſtands an end!
sp.stage: [Violent knocking at both cloſets and at the doors.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Save me, Mr. Goldfinch! Protect me! Ah!

div.stage: [Sulky and Milford burſt open the cloſets and ſeize on the bond and promiſe: then open the chamber doors, at one of which enter Jenny with lights, and at the other Sophia, Harry Dornton, and Mr Dornton.]

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Dear, ma', what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where is the will? [Silky recovers himſelf and ſnatches it up] Give it me, you old ſcoundrel! Give it me this inſtant, or I'll throttle you!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: So, gentlemen! You are a pretty pair of knaves!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And you are a very worthy lady!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, man!—Don't talk to me!—I ſhall never recover my ſenſes again!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What has happened, gentlemen? How came you thus all locked up together?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you here, Mr. Silky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes! There's the honeſt, grateful, friendly Mr. Silky! Who would betray his friends, plunder the living, and defraud the dead, for the eaſe of his conſcience, and to provide for his family!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Old one! You're done up!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And here is the girliſh old coquette, who would rob her daughter and leave her huſband's ſon, to rot in a dungeon, that ſhe might marry the firſt fool ſhe could find.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Widow! You are diſhed! [Sulky examines the will] Loſt your laſt chance!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A broken gameſter, nurtured in idleneſs, ignorance, and diſſipation, whoſe ridings, racings, and drivings are over, and whoſe whole train of horſes, dogs, curricles, phaetons, and fooleries muſt come to the hammer immediately, is no great loſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh, la! And what is coming to the hammer?

p.q: Oh, the hammer is an inſtrument by which Folly is publickly knocked down to the beſt bidder; after which ſhe riſes, gambols, whiſks away, makes a ſhort flying tour, and gallops back to be publickly knocked down again.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: "Dear!—Poor Mr Goldfinch,"

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I knew your father, ſir: 'tis happy for him that he is dead! If you will forſake theſe courſes and apply to trade—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn trade; Who's for the ſpring meeting? Croſs 'em and wind 'em! ſeven to five you don't name the winner! I'm for life and a curricle! A cut at the caſter, and the long odds! damn trade, the four aces, a back hand, and a lucky nick! I'm a deep one: That's your ſort! [Exit,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And now, madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Keep off, monſter! You ſmell of malice, cruelty and perſecution!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: No, madam: I ſmell of honeſty! A drug you nauſeate, but with which you muſt forcibly be doſed;—I have glanced over the will, and find I have the power:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let me go, goblin!—You are a hideous perſon, and I hate the ſight of you! Your breaſt is flint!—Flint! Unfeeling Gorgon, and I abominate you:

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, you are a kind, good, croſs old ſoul; and I am ſure you will forgive my poor ma', we ought all to forget and forgive: Ought not we, Mr Dornton,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [With rapture, and looking to his father] do you hear her, ſir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry has told me of your innocent, pure, and unſuſpecting heart—I love you for having called me an ugly monſter;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [To Harry] La, Mr Dornton, how could you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Harry—Give me your hand—You have a generous and a noble nature! But your generoſity would have proved more pernicious than even your diſſipation. No misfortunes, no not the beggary and ruin of a father, could juſtify ſo unpricipled a marriage!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And now [To Mr Sulky] my friend,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: My father—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My—!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whoo! If you wiſh to get another word from me to night, have done. [Turning to Silky] I hate fawning!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, Mr Sulky, you will have your humour,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The undiſcriminating generoſity of this young man ſupported you in your day of diſtreſs; for which, ſerpent-like, you turned to ſting your preſerver,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, you will have your humour,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p:
Yes; and it is my humour to ſee that your villany ſhall be expoſed in its true colours. Hypocriſy, falſehood, and fraud, are your familiars. To ſcreen
〈1 page duplicate〉
your avarice, you made it believed that this gentleman had been the cauſe of lodging the detainders, and had done the dirty work of which even you were aſhamed. But the creditors receive their full demand.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The propoſal is juſt. Liſten to that worthy man; and if you can, be honeſt with a good grace. Every thing will then be readily adjuſted, and I hope to the ſatisfaction of all parties.
